title: 2 minutes 2 midnight
description: First VST YouTube recording

Even though this song would be recorded at the end of the Beatles time together, it was one of the first songs that Lennon and McCartney wrote together. I have added horns in the place of the guitar licks that Lennon recorded.

title: Achillies last stand
description: As far as length of a song is concerned, this is the longest song that I have recorded. Jimmy Page has four guitar tracks on this song and I have programmed three of the tracks to be played as string instruments.

title: All along the watchtower
description: Bob Dylan originally wrote and recorded this song, but I am partial to the Jimi Hendrix version. At the same time, I try to sing it like Dylan's version with Hendrix mixed in as well.

title: All my loving
description: I have always believed that the origins of Punk Rock came from skiffle music. As a result, I played a distorted guitar. Also, I do not have a great enough guitar to play it with distortion, without it resulting in fluctuating volume, which happens when you play a 1980s $350 guitar. Distortion pedals will process the tones and send out a consistent signal.

title: Amok Time
description: Song number 233 is one of my favorites. I had to seek the aide of two musicians Justin Ashouri and his friend to transcribe the music to the second movement of this song 'Amok Time' - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Amok-Time.mp3

title: And I love her
description: I did not play the second guitar in the later half of the song because the Beatles change the key signature and I have not figured out how to play the second guitar in the new key.

title: Angels and Sailors Stoned Emmaculate Feast of Friends
description: A few years after Jim Morrison passed away, the rest of the Doors recorded music to the poems that he recorded before his passing. Most of the lyrics are too vulgur for radio play and, as a result, not people know of the American Prayer album released in 1979. These are my three favorite tracks from that album. I had to seek the aide of two musicians Justin Ashouri and his friend to transcribe the Angels and Sailors guitar track.

title: Anything goes tonight
description: I do not believe that I have a voice that can do justice to Axel Rose. Yet, I have had countless people tell me that I sound like him. Granted, I try to use a voice similar to the voice he used during the verse portions of Its so easy, but the high notes. Sorry, I am not there yet. Finished the vocals on 'Anything goes tonight' uploaded - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Anything-goes-tonight.mp3

title: Are you experienced
description: This song is difficult for me to play, because there are no hooks from the bass or drums for me to know when it is about to change to the chorus, end of the lead, etc... Of course, until it is too late. As a result, the guitar track is off timing in some parts, which lead to the vocal track being out of synch as well. I love playing the lead to 'Are you experienced' - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=R-U-Experienced.mp3

title: Atomic Punk
description: Once again, my guitar does not have the functionality of a top tier guitar. I still love my guitar and do the best that I can with what I have. As a result, it cannot pick up all the subtle movements of the palm of my hand to replicate what Eddie has done on the original.

title: Avalanches
description: Thanks to some urging on by my best friend, Carol, whom convinced me before she left her body on April 8th 2011, two days after my birthday, that I should honor my first best friend, Delbert, who passed away when I was 11 years old. After Delberts passing, I received all kinds of inspiration to write all of these songs. However, I did not share them with anyone until it was looking more and more that the time for my best friend was coming to its course. The following songs: Avalanches, Friends and To the One were inspired to me a few months before turning the age of twelve. I would like to thank Carol, for pushing me to finally record these songs.It was 1975, when Delbert left his body. Thanks for being kind to me, when everyone else was so cruel.I would relish seeing you each morning while we would be hall patrol monitors.I still miss that smiling face of yours.Even when some kids would use the 'N' word directed at you.You showed me,	that what you think of yourself is more important than what others think of you.And everyone knows that I love myself. The big question to me is, why doesnt everyone else. I love all of my friends and family. Yeah, basically anyone who loves me. After a suggestion from a friend (Jak Delany), I have re-recorded and remixed. Now you can hear everything more clearly

title: Back in the day
original_band: Music by Rush Lyrics by KRONUS Productions L.L.C.
description:
A few days after Carol passed away, these lyrics came to me. We both came to California in the 80s, when it was a loving and giving place. We would eventually become neighbors in 2003 and she became one of my seven best friends, along with being the last to pass away.

I recorded the lyrics over the last portion of a Rush cover "Camera Eye," because this song reminds me of the 80s and how much optimism, driven competition and fun there was associated with that time period

It is only fitting that these lyrics would go to music like this, which we both loved.

Here are the lyrics:

Since you've been gone
There's no place that I belong
Just as another passing dawn
Find a way to go on

We knew, this day would come
& while easier said than done
like having fun
You were the one

& how can I say
tomorrow is better than today
when it always
leads me to
back in the day

title: Bad Boy
description: The Beatles recorded many Larry Williams' songs and you cannot find them in print these days, because of copyright rules. I am old enough to have purchased these tunes when they were in print. This is one of my favorite Larry Williams' songs. Another song from the skiffle genre, which is the pre-cursor to Punk Rock, which is why I recorded it with distorted guitar.

title: Barracuda
description: Obviously, if I am just beginning to understand how to use my voice, then it will be a while before I am able to sing the likes of songs such as this, but I still love it enough to record it.

title: Bastille Day
description: After recording Carol's favorite songs of the songs that I play, this was the second song that I recorded.

title: Bennie and the jets
description: Butchered another classic 'Bennie and the Jets' piano is not perfect, but I love playing it - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Bennie-and-the-jets.mp3

title: Best part of a man
description:
I do not know why Van Halen named this song "Full Bug" when the chorus repeats 'Best part of a man,' so I named my version 'Best part of a man'

This is one of my favorite Van Halen songs and it's too bad that I do not do a great of playing it, but I love to play it, regardless.

The album "Diver Down" gave Van Halen the first world wide number one hit and placed among the world's greatest bands, which lead to being the headliner for the US Festival in 1982.

At that point, I had been trying to tell people for years that Van Halen should be taken seriously and this was my validation.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E major.

Intro is a series of notes played with a counter point to E.

Verse:
E (I), A (IV) followed by a series notes that continues to resolve to E (I), G (iii), E (I), D (vii)

Bridge:
A7 (IV7), E7 (I7)

Chorus:
D7 (vii7) played twice, B7 (V7) to Bdim (v) to B5 (V5)

The guitar lead is played over E7 (I7) and the harmonica is played over the bridge and chorus progressions.

Two takes for the guitar and two takes with the vocals, with a handful of punch ins (for timing purposes).

The harmonica solo isn't perfect but it's what I could figure out and hopefully someone can take it to the next level.

title: Between the wheels
description: I love playing the lead in this song.

title: Black dog
description: It took four takes and for several reasons, like not selecting the correct track, but I got it done.

title: When youre with me
description:
This is a KRONUS Productions L.L.C. original "When you're with me" that I wrote on the weekend of 03.11.18

I originally started off working with some swing type of music, but since I didn't save the entire song, I started over and it flowed like wine.

The song is played in the key of D major

Verse:
I (pull offs with sus4 and major third) vii vi V7

Chorus:
ii V - repeat four times

bridge:
iii (with a sus minor 7) v iv# vii vi V7 I

Lyrics:
Verse 1:
I can see
we're all family

Chorus:
When you're with me
love is all around
When you're with me
nothing gets me down

Verse 2:
Because little girls should run d world
kittens, puppies and rainbows

Chorus:

Verse 3:
I don't know if I'll make it to Heaven
because I've already been

Chorus:

title: What r u able 2 build with your blocks
description: This song is called "Blocks", the lyrics are a poem by Robert Louis Stevenson "What are you able to build with your blocks"

title: Bohemian Rhapsody
description: This song was Clyde Johnson's favorite song. He used to play it over and over in the 70s. My late best friend and neighbor, Clyde Johnson, who was a gay jewish man that was always hoping his partner would see the light and settle down with him, but it wasn't meant to be. With that said, he had a little part of himself that wished he could be adventurious. Then maybe he would have hit the road with his partner. However, he owned an antique store and wasn't about to give everything up for something that might not have lasted. That inspired me to write Bonnie and Clyde. Hope he has someone that will be true to him in Heaven.

title: Bonnie and Clyde
description: This was a song that was inspired by my late best friend and neighbor, Clyde Johnson, who was a gay jewish man that was always hoping his partner would see the light and settle down with him, but it wasn't meant to be. With that said, he had a little part of himself that wished he could be adventurious. Then maybe he would have hit the road with his partner. However, he owned an antique store and wasn't about to give everything up for something that might not have lasted. That inspired me to write Bonnie and Clyde. Hope he has someone that will be true to him in Heaven.

title: Border Song
description: I have loved Elton John since I first heard Rocketman back in the early seventies. I owe a lot of my understanding of music theory to Elton. While I was working a graveyard shift in a parking garage in the late eighties, I basically watched parked cars. As a result of the nature of my position, my boss did not mind if read while sitting in my booth. I chose to study Elton's music. I would break down each note in it's relation to the key signature, then I would look for patterns. I did this with many songs, but Elton's music was the first.

title: Bottoms Up
description: This is a Van Halen cover off of their second album. I loved their first album and I kept track of the band. I was very pleased when I heard their second album in 1979 and I have been often asked what is my favorite King Edward lead. Guess what, it is tied with "Light up the sky," "I'm the one," "I'm on fire," you get the picture... They're all my favorite

title: Cant buy me love
description:
This is a Beatles cover and, while I would hear Beatle songs on the radio, I had no idea that all those songs were from one group.

After my uncle purchased the 1967-1970, which had just been released in 1973. I feel in love and purchased the 1962-1966, which was released in the same year and this song was on side one of that album.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of C major

Intro:
Em (iii), Am (vi), Em (iii), Am (vi), Dm7 (ii7), G6 (V6)

Verse:
C7 (I7), F7 (IV7), C7 (I7), G7 (V7), F (IV7)

The intro is used as a bridge that returns to the verse and lead is played over the verse progression.

The intro is also used for the outro

Follow:
https://twitter.com/KRONUSProd
Download Tab/Midi:
http://kronusproductions.com/songs_angular

This song is number 28 on the list, page 1

title: Castles made of sand
description:
I found the background guitar midi for this song on the internet. I do not know who programmed it, but thank you. I hope they do not mind that I have changed a few things.

This is a Jimi Hendrix cover off of his "Axis: Bold as Love" album. I would get into Hendrix during my high school years at Bellaire Sr. High in Bellaire, TX. What can I say, he became one of my many guitar idols. 

If you look at many of leads, then you can see that I always include a minor pentatonic scale, which mixes with a major diatonic scale, with a pinch of blues pentatonic added. Of course, one could argue that every great guitarist does that, but Hendrix was the first.

This is the first time that I am using the Fishman Triple Play via Orange Tree Sample Statosphere, ironically enough their preset is called "Bold Love." There is a slight delay that I had to account for and not bad for a first take.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of G major. The intro is played in G major

Verse:
Fsus2 (viisus2), Am (ii), Em7 (vi7)

The lead is played entirely over a G major chord

Each verse begins with the intro played in G major.

Music historians should take note that before Hendrix, everything used to follow a blues progression, either in the key of E or A, but Hendrix busts out of that cage and gives us a progression that was never heard in popular music, until that he did it.

Beethoven is known for realizing the power of resolving a tone, from seventh to tonic, second to tonic or Aeolian to tonic. Notice how Hendrix uses all three and resolves to tonic with the play of the intro in between the progressions. Along with the lyrics, to keep the listener unresolved until the chorus, where he frees them with the words of wisdom "Castles made of sand..."

title: Celebration Day
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover and, more specific, the live version off of "The Song Remains the Same" or commonly known as TSRTS

What the four of these guys do, is much more difficult than it sounds, especially their live material. They have a raw sound that I have strived to find for myself, except to be unique, of course.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of A major and it switches to the key of C major during the chorus.

Intro:
G7 (vii7), G#7(VII#7), A7 (I7)

Verse:
A (I) it is a play on an old blues lick and repeated throughout

Chorus (switches to the key of C major):
C7 (I7), G7 (V7), Bb (vii), F (IV)
C7 (I7), G7 (V7), Bb (vii), F7 (IV7), E7 (vi7) 

The chorus is classic Beethoven, tonic to dominant, to minor seventh, to subdominant, followed by repeating, but ending with Aeolian 7th, which points to tonic. To elaborate more, Beethoven was always trying to do tension followed by resolve

As usual, I record all mistakes or wrongs and this is from the second take, not bad. I am telling you guys, until you try to do the drumming, bass, guitar or vocals, you will not appreciate how great these four guys are doing

title: Change the world
description: I have always been afraid of playing a Clapton song because I am not a great guitarist, but this came out better than I could have imagined - song number 209 "Change the world" - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Change-the-world.mp3 Also, I did not program the midi for this song

title: Children of the Grave
description:
I chose to play the Randy Rhodes version, but I incorporated some of the drum techniques of the Black Sabbath version, along with the bass. This is an Ozzy Osbourne with Randy Rhoads cover. I had to opportunity to go to an Ozzy show with Randy and I said that I would catch them the next time they were in town. Should have gone

It has been a while since I played some Randy and it opens my heart with joy, passion and enthusiasm. 

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of E major.

Intro:
C#5 (vi5), E5 (I5), A (IV5), B (V5), C#5 (vi5)

Verse:
C#5 (vi5)

Bridge:
You can see the tab for the series of notes played and they are followed by this progression repeated twice, then back to the intro
C#5 (vi5), E5 (I5), C#5 (vi5), G#5 (III5), G5 (iii5), G#5 (III5), A#5 (IV#5), B5 (V5)
C#5 (vi5), E5 (I5), C#5 (vi5), B5 (V5), A#5 (IV#5), B5 (V5)

The lead is played over the intro progression.

As with all my recordings, I record all mistakes or wrongs and this is from the second take, not bad. This song is straight forward but I had to keep adjusting the bass because my system couldn't handle all that double bass, without throttling back on the bass in the sends.

title: Circumstances
description:
This is a Rush cover off of their "Hemispheres" album. I had the chance to go to this tour as well and I complained about flour tickets being $17.50. What can I say, that was a lot of money for kid in the 70s, especially compared to what it used to be. Yeah, that was inflation back then. Boy, I would gladly take those prices back.

Anyways, according to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of C major.

Intro:
Am (vi), Bm (vii), Am (vi), G (V), D (ii)

Verse:
B (vii), G (V), D (ii), A/C# (vi/I#), D (ii), F# (IV#) repeat

Bridge:
G (V), B (vii), C (I), A (vi), D (ii), D#o (ii#o), E (iii)

Chorus:
Am (vi), Bm (vii), Am (vi), G (V), D (ii), C (I), D (ii)
Am (vi), Bm (vii), Am (vi), G (V), D (ii), Cm (i), Am (vi) 

I play it slightly different than the sheet music, by playing Cm before moving to Am

Interlude:
C (I), D (ii), C (I), D (ii), E (iii)
A (vi), B (vii), A (vi), B (vii)
C (I), D (ii), C (I), D (ii)
A (vi), B (vii), C (I), D (ii), C (I), D (ii), C (I), D (ii), E (iii)
C (I), D (ii), C (I), D (ii), E (iii)

The VST guitar, along with my guitar, give it a richer and fuller sound. You can hear the difference when I fade out my guitar during the interlude and return for the ending. Together they sound great and separate they sound weak, for lack of a better term.

title: Closer to the heart
description:
This is a Rush cover off of their "Farewell to Kings" album. My sister's favorite Rush song, "Cygnus X-1," is on that same album. I am blessed to have been born at a time where I could experience such songs in real time as they happened.

This is the most popular song on that album and it allowed for an opportunity to introduce this awesome band to a larger audience. This song has five guitar tracks and I am only playing one of the lead tracks.

If you listen to my old recording of this cover (http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Closer-to-the-heart.mp3) then you can hear that I use all of my fingers on the acoustic guitar, without the use of a pic. As a result, I had to record a separate track for the rhythm and lead, which I did not want to do this time around.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of A major.

You can see the pattern of notes played from the tab/midi in the intro which finishes the following progression:
G6 (vii6), D (IV), Fmaj7 (vib7), Asus2 (Isus2), Asus4 (Isus4), A (I), Asus2 (Isus2), Asus4 (Isus4), A (I)

Verse:
A (I), G (vii), D (IV), G (vii), A (I)
A (I), G (vii), D (IV), A (I), G (vii), D (IV), A (I), G (vii)

The lead is played over the verse progression and ends with the intro, minus the aforementioned progression.

Other than the intro pattern of notes, I would have to say that this is one of their more simple songs to play. Ironic that I am only recording the lead portion, but as I stated above, there are five guitar parts and the VSTs, along with the tab, give you clear picture of how this can be played.

title: Come on
description:
This is a Stevie Ray Vaughan cover, which is his cover of a Hendrix song "Come on." I was inspired to become better, when I would see his picture in the same clubs in Texas that I played in, back in the 80s. I tried to combine both Stevie Ray Vaughn and Hendrix version to make my own I guess. 

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E major and it follows a standard blues progression

E7 (I7), A7 (IV7), E7 (I7), A7 (IV7), E7 (I7), B7 (V7), A7 (IV7), Em7 (i7)

There is a chromatic progression that acts as an intro to the lead and it is also used to end the song

F#5 (ii5), G5 (iii5), G#5 (III5), A5 (IV5), A#5 (IV#5) pause B5 (V5), B#5 (V#5), C#5 (vi5), D5 (vii5), D#5 (VII5)

If you feel like you are listening to Hendrix, when you listen to Vaughan, then it is because they do the same things, like flowing in and out of major and minor pentatonic scales, with a dash of blues pentatonic added for flavor.

One of the keys to sounding like either of them, is that they play the guitar with heavy hand that is flexible. Beat the guitar up, like you are in a fight and then play with it, like it's a child that you are tickling.

This is my first time to record using the Casio MG-510, while I am not using the midi portion of the guitar, it does have a natural Strat sound.

As usual, I record my mistakes and this was the fifth take. I keep getting lost in the melodic section of the first lead. It's pretty straight forward and I do not understand why, but on the fifth take, I gave into the Universe, that it wants it this way.

title: Comfortably numb
description:
This is a Pink Floyd cover and I first heard this the day that the album, "The Wall," came out. I remember being amazed at both the lyrics and the music of this ground breaking moment in time.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of D major

Verse:
Bm (vi), A (V), G G/F# Em7 (IV IV/III ii7), Bsus2 (vi sus2)

Bridge:
D (I), A (V), D (I), A (V), C (vii), G (IV), C (vii), G (IV) repeat

Chorus:
Asus4 (V sus4), Asus2 (V sus2), A (V), G/B (IV/vi), Csus2 (vii sus2), G5 (IV5), D (I)

The first lead is played over the bridge progression and the second lead is played over the verse progression.

I am sure that if I had my guitar going through my amp, then I could have had the sustain needed to make the first lead smoother, but I have neighbors and that means being good to them, so that I can continue living here.

title: Communication Breakdown
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover and many of my favorite bands have done a cover of this song. It is a powerful garage band type of hard rocking number and it pre dates what people think of as "punk rock" by a decade.

This used to be the second song of my set, when I played in public, all those years ago. It followed "Fire" a Jimi Hendrix cover.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E major and it follows some standard blues progression patterns.

Intro and verse:
E (I), D A D E (vii IV vii I)

Chorus:
A7 (IV7), B7 (V7)

Most rock/pop songs coming out of the 50s and 60s followed a similar pattern, but with John Bonham and John Paul Jones thumbing behind Jimmy Page, with the force of Robert Plant singing, it gave new life to this progression.

I love it.

title: Crazy Train
description:
This is an Ozzy cover with Randy Rhodes. I love this song. When I first heard it in high school, I was actually trying to stay away from music, parties, etc... and concentrate on my studies. A friend of mine from school put in the tape during lunchtime and I asked who is that on guitar and he laughed, followed by asking me where I have been for the past two years.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of A major.

Intro:
F#5 (vi5), A5 (I5), E5 (V5), F#5 (vi5), D5 (IV5), E5 (V5) played an octave above the first E5
Series of notes are all played over this same progression

Verse:
A (I), E/A (V/I), D/A (IV/I)

Bridge:
F#5 (vi5), D5 (IV5)

Chorus:
A5 (I5), E5 (V5), F#m (vi)

Bridge 2 plays the same progression as the intro progression

The lead is played over the following progression:
F#m (vi), E5 (V5), D (IV), C#5 (III), Bm (ii), A (I), A/G# (I/VII) last repeat of progression ends on E5 (V5)

Outro is the same progression as the intro.

As usual, a couple of mistakes but you know by now that I record all my mistakes.

title: Crazy on you
description:
This is a Heart cover and I remember being blown away when I heard the absolute perfection of this song. It has many things that I love, incorporated into one song. Acoustic guitar, with hard rockin guitar mixed in, harmony vocals mixed with a powerful lead vocals, etc...

It's too bad that I can not sing as well as I play other instruments. If you get a chance to treat yourself, then put on some head phones and listen to Ann Wilson's awesome voice.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of C major.

I will not cover the intro solo, but here is the rest of the song.

Intro:
Am (vi), F (IV) repeated, Am (vi), G (V), Am (vi), F (IV)

Verse:
Am (vi), C (I), Dm (ii), I play an E7 (iii7) but the sheet music has just an E

Chorus is played with the intro progression

Bridge:
F#m (iv#), I play a B7 (vii7) but the sheet music has D, I play a C#7 (i#7) sheet music C#m, D (ii), C#7 (i#7), D (ii), C#7 (i#7), Bm7 (vii7), A (vi), E (iii)

There are two solos and the first is played over the progression of the intro.

The second solo is played over the progression of the bridge.

As usual, a couple of mistakes but you know by now that I record all my mistakes. However, I smack the guitar around so much on this song, that I had to decrease the gain by 4 db, along with lowering the volume to negative 5 db.

As a result, you may still a hear a couple of distortions from time to time.

title: Crazy
description:
This is a Guns 'N Roses cover, "You're Crazy," and I was in LA when this album came out, specifically the hit single "Welcome to Jungle" on a local TV show called "Smash or Trash," which aired the video. A viewer could call in to vote on whether it was smash or trash. I called in on the line that it was a smash.

GnR would later put out the album "Appetite for Destruction" which I fell in love with and I still say that the drumming is what made these songs special. They fit perfect with Slash's guitar, Axel's voice and lyrics.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Intro and verse:
G (V), G# (v#)
G (V) A (vi) G (V) A (vi) G (V) A (vi) D (ii)
G (V) A (vi) G (V) A (vi) G (V) A (vi) E (iii)

Bridge:
D (ii), E (iii), D (ii), C (I)

Chorus non-chords and mainly single notes/riffs in G with the interlude of three descending chromatic chords:
E5 (iii5), Eb (iiib), D5 (ii5)

Intro to lead:
D (ii)
E (iii), G (V), F#5 (IV#), E (iii)
A (vi), C (I), B (vii), A (vi)

The lead is played over the same progression as the verse.

As usual, a couple of mistakes but you know by now that I record all my mistakes.

title: Crocodile Rock
description:
This is an Elton John cover and I was in love with Elton John long before I was in love with the Beatles and Elvis. As a matter of fact, it was because of Elton John doing a Beatles cover "Lucy in the sky with Diamonds" that I discovered the Beatles. Coming home from soccer practice while Carl Walberg was driving his brother, Eric Walberg, and I home, when the Beatles' version of "Lucy in the sky with Diamonds" came on the radio and I remarked, "look at this band trying to copy Elton." They both laughed at me and Eric said, "these are the Beatles" and I replied, "who are the Beatles?" Carl was laughing so hard that he had to pull over. Ironically, my uncle was staying with us temporarily while he studied English, so that he could attend Penn State University for his PHD in Agriculture and had just purchased two albums. Elvis live at madison garden and the Beatles 1967-1970.

I listened to the double album and I had heard all these songs on the radio, but I had no idea that it was from one band. Needless to say, both the Beatles and Elvis replace Elton John as my favorite artist. Of course, a few years later I would be introduced to Rush and they would replace both Elvis and the Beatles as my favorite band, but Elton is my first love, so to say.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of G major.

Intro:
G/D (I/V), C/G (IV/I), GËš/F# (i/VII)
G (I), Em (vi), C (IV), D (V) classic pop progression which is based of Beethoven's work

Verse:
G (I), Bm (iii), C (IV), D (V)

Bridge:
Em (vi) D (V) repeated four times Em (vi), I play an A7 (IV7), but the music says A (IV)
D (V), G (I), E7 (vi7), A7 (IV7)

Chorus:
D (V), C (IV) followed by the progress of the intro, which also acts as the outro

title: Crosstown Traffic
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover and it is too bad for the world, that he passed away shortly after recording this tune. He was working with legends such as Miles Davis, Edgar Winter, John Lennon, etc... when this was recorded. Who knows where he could have taken it to what level.

I loved this song from the moment that I heard it. It has a Motown feeling to it.

According to the sheet music that I have, it is played in the key of C# major

As with many Hendrix songs, from "Axis:Bold as Love" album onward, he was always trying to break out of the box and does so with this one.

While seventh and ninth chords are not new to jazz, but back then, they were new to rock.

Intro:
B7 (vii7), C#7#9 (I9), F#7#9 (IV9) repeat and end on B7

Verse:
C#7#9 (I9), F#7#9 (IV9) repeat Bm7 (vii7), E7b9 (iii9), Am7 (vib7), G#7b5 (V7b5) Hendrix mainly makes feedback noises with these last four chords

The chorus is a repeat of the intro progression, except it starts with C#7#9

The "lead" and outro also use the same progression.

I use the same settings for my Randy Rhodes recordings for this one.

title: Daniel
description: "Daniel" recorded and uploaded - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Daniel.mp3

title: Day of the Eagle
description:
This is a Robin Trower cover and I have seen him play live twice. The first time in 1985, I was front row and by the stage. While I loved watching him play, the crowd pushing on my back was not appreciated and I probably would have liked the show more had it not been for that aspect. As a result, the second time was enjoyed from a distance.

I have loved Robin Trower for so long that I used to have an eight track tape of him and I listen to it often. He was the closest thing to Hendrix, until Stevie Ray Vaughan came on the scene.

I do not have sheet music for this, only tabs from the net and according to that it is in the key of C major, but I beg to differ and I would say it is in the key of D major

Intro:
B7sus4 (vi7 sus4) followed by a series notes

Verse:
D (I), Bm (vi), followed by the same notes as are in the intro, then Dsus7m (I sus7m), D#sus7m (I# sus7m), Esus7m (ii sus7m)

The lead is played over the verse progression. One could argue that the bridge is the Bm and the chorus are chord progressions played along the three bottom strings.

title: Dead or Alive
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their second album. I love many songs that Van Halen has and, maybe it is because that is what I first heard, but I love their first two albums more than any of their others.

Once again, I cannot plug into my amp because I need to remain living in these apartments, without my neighbors having me thrown out. Otherwise, I could get the feedback effect needed for some of the whammy bar action that is need to do this song justice

It took five takes, but much of that had to do with technical issues, like only having the left side of the channel plugged. Yes, really. Otherwise, it went pretty smooth. Some of the timing in the vocals was off, but I did not want to record another take.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major.

Intro:
A (I), E (V), F# (vi)

Verse:
A (I), E (V), F# (vi)

Chorus:
C#5 (iii5), D5 (IV5), C#5 (iii5), D5 (IV5), E (V5)

The lead is played over the following progression:
A (I), E (V), A (I), F# (vi), A (I), F# (vi), A (I), B (ii), C# (iii), D (IV), C# (iii)

The second lead changes the progression by playing the last part first:
A (I), B (ii), C# (iii), D (IV), C# (iii), A (I), E (V), A (I), F# (vi), A (I), F# (vi)

As usual, I record all my mistakes, some in the first lead and in the outro.

title: Desperado
description:
This is an Eagles cover and I was introduced to this one in 1987, which is long after it was released in 1973. For some reason, I did not hear about it until I was dating a girl named Karen Young and she played this song for me, which pushed away from her and towards having sex with woman that she knew and she was a waitress at a bar, whehew.

I miss you Karen, wherever you are, may you be blessed. She could always put a smile on my face, as I with her. We had a completely plutonic relationship with a lot of sexual innuendoes.

Anytime I hear this song or "The boys of summer" by Don Henley, ironic that he sings both of them, I think of her and it puts a melancholy smile on my face. 

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major

Intro and Outro:
G6 (I6), C6 (IV6), G6 (I6) the sheet music says G7, but I see it as a G6

Verse:
G (I), G7sus2 (I7 sus2), C (IV), Cm6 (iv6), G (I), Em7 (vi7), A7 (ii7), D7 (V7) repeat and end with D7/F# (V7/VII) I only play a D7

Chorus:
Em7 (vi7), Bm7 (iii7), C (IV), G (I), D7/F# (V7/VII) I just play a D7
Em7 (vi7), Em (vi), C (IV), G, D/F# (V/VII) I only play a D7 
repeat and I end with A7 (ii7), D7 (V7)

I know my vocals do not do this song justice, but I am getting much better and I plan to get a lot better as time rolls along. That is the one thing that I regret in life, is not putting in as much time for vocals, as I have for all the other instruments, but I thought I would find a singer by now.

As usual all mistakes are recorded, with no overdubs or punch ins

title: Different strings
description:
This is a Rush cover off of their Permanent Waves album. I actually still have a vinyl copy. I remember when this album came out, as if it was yesterday.

While songs like "Spirit of Radio" signaled a change was coming and was on the radio all the time, I gravitated to songs like this one.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Intro:
Am7 (vi7), D/A (ii/vi), Am (vi)

Verse:
D9 no 3rd (ii9), CM7 (IM7), D9 (ii9), Am (vi), D9 (ii9), CM7 (IM7), D9 (ii9), Am (vi), D9 (ii9), CM7 (IM7), D9 (ii9)

Bridge:
Bm11 (vii11), F (IV), Bm11 (vii11), F (IV), G (V), A (vi)

Chorus:
G/F (V/IV), F (IV), G/F (V/IV), Am (vi), FM9 (IVM9), G6 (V6), Am7 (vi7)

The outro lead is played over the following progression:
A (vi), A/D (vi/ii), C (I), D (ii)

I had to lower the tempo to 110 from 130 to be able to play this on time.

As usual all mistakes are recorded, with no overdubs or punch ins

title: Distant early warning
description:
This is a Rush cover off of their Grace Under Pressure album, which I still have a vinyl copy. This song came at a time when nuclear holocaust was ever present and it was one of many songs in the 80s that brought about a conscience effort of the masses to call for Peace.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Intro and Verse:
Am7 (vi7), C (I), Em7 (iii7) repeat and end with Am7 on the fifth fret. I mix in a G (V) an octave higher than the one played later on in the song.

D7sus4/A (ii7 sus4/vi), D7 (ii7), Am (vi) 4 times, F (IV), G (V) repeat twice

Chorus:
Dm (ii), C (I), Dm (ii), F (IV), G (V)

The lead is played over the chorus progression and ending with verse progression.

As usual all mistakes are recorded, except for the vocals that were sliced and moved, this was for timing purposes.

title: Dont let the sun go down on me
description:
This is an Elton John cover and heard this around '74. Elton (Reggie) was putting out one hit after another. I feel privileged to have lived during this time period.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Intro & Interlude:
C (I), C/Bb (I/viib), F/A (IV/vi), C/G (I/V), F (IV)

Verse:
G (V), G7 (V7), F/C (IV/I), C (I), F/C (IV/I), C (I), C/E (I/iii), F (IV), G (V), C/G (I/V), G (V), C/G (I/V)
G (V), C/G (I/V), F/C (IV/I), C (I), F/C (IV/I), C (I), C7/E (I7/iii), F (IV), G (V), C/G (I/V), G (V), C/G (I/V)

Repeat two more times and end with:
G (V), F/G (IV/V)

Chorus:
C (I), C/Bb (I/viib), Am7 (vi7), D7/F# (ii7/IV#), C/G (I/V), F/G (IV/V), G7 (V7), C (I), C/Bb (I/viib), F/A (IV/vi)

Turnaround:
Dm7 (ii7), C/E (I/iii), F (IV), C/G (I/V), F/G (IV/V) I play this with different inversions of C over C

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Down in southern Alabama
description:
This is a KRONUS Productions L.L.C. original, that I used to play in the 80s. This is when people would tell me after a performance, "if you could sing, then you would be bigger than Elvis"

I took it as a complement, because I never worked on the one instrument, that probably could have made a big difference. I had always assumed that I would meet a singer and they would handle their portion of the song.

All of this electronic instruments was supposed to be temporary back in '91. I figured, that at some point, other musicians would see me play and the ideas that I had for other instruments, which would be followed by, "hey I like your jams, would you be interested in playing together some time"

And while I have been offered a few handful of times to collaborate, either some drama would ensue or the musician could not perform what my computer could do, anytime that I requested and as often as I requested.

Kind of difficult to acquire such skill and discipline when you are not being paid. Never the less, the result was for me to have been taught all these areas of music that I probably would have never touched, had I been in a band that was successful early.

I am following basic Beethoven and this is in the key of A major.

Intro & Verse:

A (I)

Chorus:
A (I), E (V), D (IV) repeat twice

The lead is played over the verse and chorus progressions.

Pretty straight forward and, believe it or not, this is what most songs in the 50s and 60s where based on this progression. The difference between what I am doing and what they were doing, is that, they were playing to a Pentecostal back beat, whereas, I am reversing the beat of a Waltz, which is the same thing that ZZ Top, AC/DC, The Beatles (early 60s) etc... used to do.

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Eleanor Rigby
description:
This is a Beatles cover and I would play this song, when my Father would complain that I listen to nothing but garbage. Of course, Paperback Writer would come on afterwards and he would return to his mad state.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major.

Intro & Chorus:
C (IV), Em (vi) repeat

Verse:
Em (vi), C (IV), Em (vi), Em7 (vi7), C (IV), Em (vi)

Bridge:
Em7 (vi7), Em6 (vi6), C/E (IV/VI), Em (vi) repeat

This song's only mistakes were one section of my vocals (timing), but either way, all mistakes are recorded. No reason to cover up my humanity.

title: Electric Eye
description:
This is a Judas Priest cover that was released in 1982. The group was soon marked by right wing moral conservatives as Satanic worshippers, but we know now that Judas Priest was letting the world know that they were being watched by their own governments.

I love this song and I love playing it. Of course, it is no coincidence that the guitar track was recorded in one take and the vocals in two takes, with a couple of mistakes in the beginning guitar part, but not bad.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major.

Intro:
E (vi), E (vi), D (V), C (IV), D (V)

Pre-verse:
E (vi), A (ii), B (iii), C (IV), A (ii)
D to E (V to vi) repeated four times

Verse:
G to A (I to ii) repeated four times, D to E (V to vi) repeated four times followed by the pre-verse progression

Chorus, kind of complicated but at it's simplest form:
Asus4/E (IV sus4/ vi), A/E (IV/vi), Em7 (vi7), E5 (vi5), D (V), Asus4/E (IV sus4/ vi), A/E (IV/vi), Em7 (vi7)

The lead is played over the following progression:
E to D (vi V), E to D (vi V), C5 (IV5), G5 (I5) repeat
B5 (iii5), A5 (ii5), B5 (iii5), A5 (ii5), G5 (I5) repeat and end C5 (IV5)
A5 (ii5), C5 (IV5), B5 (iii5), D5 (V5)

The last verse switches:
A D over A (ii V/ii), G C over A (I IV/ii)
A5 to B5 (ii5 to iii5)

Outro is the same as the chorus and end with:
D (V), A (ii), G (I), E (vi), D (V), G (I), E (vi)

title: Enter Sandman
description:
This is a Metallica cover and I first became aware of them on their Master of Puppets tour, when they opened for Ozzy. My bassist at the time told me all about how they had just lost their band member and no one knew if they were going to last or not. I guess they did and it was one of the best concerts that I had ever been to, that's saying a lot.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major.

The intro uses the same series of notes that are later played in F# during the bridge. Download the midi file and check it out.

Intro:
vi vi (octave above) I iiib ii vi (octave above) vi
The fourth string second fret (E) is played with the third, second and first strings played open.

Open E sixth string played with a slide to E seventh fret fifth string
The same with ending on F and adding a Bb
Then add an A with the riff now played eight times
When the drums kick in, switch to landing on E, instead of F, for four times

The famous turn around riff:
G (I), E (vi), F# (vii), E (vi), F# (vii), G (I), E (vi)

Verse:
Open E string and landing on F and add the turn around riff at the end of each verse.

Bridge:
same as the opening but played over F#

Chorus:
F# (vii), C (IV), B (iii) and end with the turn around riff

The lead is played over the intro progression just before the verse begins, followed by the bridge and chorus progressions.

It took five takes, with my Cry Baby not wanting to cooperate, which lead me to use the MXR Phase 90. Also, I am using the Casio MG-510 because there is more breathing room at fret 22, which is needed for this song.

As usual, all mistakes are recorded.

title: Eruption aint talkin about love
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their first album. As I have commented about this before, I cannot stress the impact that their first album had upon me. A couple of years before this was released, I had started getting into Rush, Black Sabbath, etc..., but this was clearly a game changer.

I also cannot emphasize enough, that Alex Van Halen is the key to bringing Eddie's unique style come to life. I do not know if I would have the same effect, had there been a more "traditional" drummer, just as I am sure the same case was for Rush. If you listen to their first album, which was with a traditional drummer, then compare it to any album with Neil and there is no way of knowning if I would love them the same.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of C major with a tempo of 138, but I play it at 130.

Intro & interlude:
Am (vi), F (IV), G (V)

Verse & Chorus & lead:
Am (vi), G (V)

The outro:
A5 (vi5), B5 (vii5), C (I)
A5 (vi5), B5 (vii5), E (iii)
repeat and end with E7 played an octave above. This should be played with the wah pedal fully closed and opened quickly, while ending on it being disabled. Of course, since my pedal does not want to cooperate, I had to use the MXR Phase 90 to simulate a wah pedal. It is ironic that King Edward also uses an MXR Phase 90 on his recording as well.

This took six takes. I tried to remove the high frequency sounds, but none the recordings came out to my satisfication, but, as usual, all mistakes are recorded, even sound engineering ones.

One might argue, to use the Casio MG-510, but I do not have the whammy bar for that guitar and the whammy bar that I have for the Ibanez, does not fit the Casio.

title: Evolution
description:
This is one of my songs that I used to play in the 80s. The end section was a place where my bass player would have a place to do a lead.

This was also the part of the show where I would talk to people about pollution, trash getting out of control, etc... and reminding my fellow man that we had to evolve, along side the technology that was evolving to quickly for us to keep up.

Of course, I was usually at bar where no one cared about pollution or any other issue, other than to get lucky.

I wrote the lyrics & music in the mid 80s, possibly 85 or 86. At the time, I did not understand music theory and I went by how it sounded.

I would have to say that this is in the key of C major.

Verse:
A (vi), G (V), F (IV), G (V) - repeat

Chorus:
A (vi), G (V)

The chorus is actually reversed, but it has been so long since I played this song, that I realized after hearing the playback, but the tension of playing G/A or A/G sounded strange to my ears and I like it.

title: Farewell to kings
description:
This is a Rush cover tune from the album with the same name as this song, which I believe it is referred to as the title track.

After falling in love with Rush, when I heard the "All the world is a stage" album in '76. This was the album that was released next and with songs such as "Xanadu" "Cygnus X-1" etc... who wouldn't love this album. 

Of course, all the love went to a song called "Closer to the Heart," which is ironic that this song makes a type of "shout out" to the song with the same name.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of D major for the intro, with it switching to the key of A.

Intro:
Bm (vi), A (V), D (I), E/G# (ii/V#), G (V), F# (iii)
D/F# (I/iii), Em/G (ii/IV), D/A (I/V), F#m/A (iii/V) A/E (V/ii)
Em (ii), Bm (vi), C (vii), G (IV), F# (iii) repeat twice then return to beginning 

Interlude and Outro (key of A):
A7sus4 (I7 sus4), A7 (I7), Em/G (v/vii), D (IV), D/F# (IV/vi), G (vii)

Bridge:
A5 (I5), D5 (IV5), B5 (ii5)

Verse:
A (I), F (vib), G (vii), E (V)

Bridge 2:
F#m (vi), G (vii), A (I)

Chorus:
G (vii), A (I) repeat three times and ending with G (vii), D/F# (IV/vi), A (I), B (ii), G (vii)

Return to bridge 1

The lead is played over a repeating bass line mixing A with an A that is played an octave above

Bridge 3:
G (vii), A (I) played two octaves below the chorus progression

I made plenty of mistakes on this song and it took me six takes, with one of the takes being not used because the camera's battery drained. Several of takes were not used because it had to do with the timing of the very beginning.

I did record the opening acoustic parts using the Fishman triple play, but nothing sounded as good as just programming in the Ample Sounds AGL2

title: Feel your love tonight
description:
This is a Van Halen cover and, yes another one from their first album, I have stated several times how much this album effected me, when I first heard it and, as a result, here's another one.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E major, which is ironic, because it seems they spend a lot of time playing A.

Intro:
G to G# (iii to III), D to E (vii to I), D (vii), C# (vi), C# to D (vi to vii), D (vii), B (V)

Verse:
A (IV), D/A (vii/IV) later verses add A on the fifth 

Chorus:
C (vib) add F#, F# (ii), B (V)

Bridge:
E5 (I5), A/E (IV/I), D5/E (vii5/I), A/E (IV/I), D (vii), E5 (I5)

The lead is played over the following progression:
A (IV), D/A (vii/IV), 
E (I), 
G# (III), A (IV), D/A (vii/IV), G# (III), 
C#5 (vi)
B5 (V5), A5 (IV),
E (I),
C5 (vib), D (vii), B (V), E (I)

Outro:
Play the bridge progression, followed by the intro

I would have done this recording in one take, but my camera's battery kept dying on me, which lead me to use my other camera's battery and one take with the other battery.

Vocals took two takes and, as usual, all mistakes were recorded with no punch ins.

title: Fight for the children
description:
This is another one of mine from the 80s. It was my second day working at a 7 11 back in 1985 and my boss new that I was pretty good at music. At the time, 7 11 used to be heavily involved in the fight for Jerry's kids (muscular dystrophy) and, back then, Jerry would have this telethon that would raise money for the cause. My boss asked me to write a song and she would get on the show to sing it. I wrote the song that day and she called in a favor. That night was my first night working the graveyard shift and I was so excited that I would not have been able to sleep, had I not been working. The night was the night that I was robbed at gun point. More specifically, the barrel of the gun was at the temple of my forehead. The group of kids had asked me why there was no relish at the hot dog area. I knew that I had filled all the bowls and I knew no one had purchased any hot dogs that night for it to be gone. I walked back there and, sure enough, all the relish was gone. I bent down to get some more from underneath the counter, when the gun was put to the temple of my forehead (right side, in case you were wondering)

The criminals got away with a whopping $19 and change. Yeah, my life was worth a little under twenty dollars and that is what I thought to myself. I cried for almost a good two hours, when a security guard came in and asked what was the matter. I told him about the burglary and filing the police report and how my life was worth under twenty dollars. He gave me a card and eventually his recommendation gave me a job working for Houston Light & Power, which turned about to be a great job, because I started studying music theory working the grave yard shift in an almost completely empty building. It worked out, but by quitting the 7 11 job, I couldn't be on the telethon. Se la vie

This song is played in the key of C major.

Chorus:
E (iii), D (ii)

Verse:
E (iii), D (ii), C (I), D (ii)

Bridge:
E (iii), F# (IV#)

The lead is played over the chorus, verse and bridge progressions

It took me four takes because I couldn't click the distortion on time when the third verse starts. Otherwise, each take was perfect.

title: Fire
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover off of his debut album and when I first heard this song, I fell in love with the drums and bass section. I also loved how the guitar wasn't always playing, that a musician could use pauses to give dramatic effect and allow the other instruments to shine, including the lyrics.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of C major.

Intro:
Ab (vib), G (V), F (IV), G (V), D (ii)

Verse:
A (vi), C (I), D (ii)

Chorus:
D9 (ii9), C9 (I9)

Interlude:
D (ii), C (I), A (vi), C (I)

The lead is played over a bass line that is played in E

Still having issues with one of my camera's batteries, but essentially this done in one take. Issues at the very end, but the rest was pretty good

title: Flight of Icarus
description:
This is an Iron Maiden cover from their Piece of Mind album. I want to say that the first Maiden song that I heard was PowerSlave and the guy that let me hear it, was dating my ex-girlfriend.

When he started playing the song, I was completely enthralled by the tune. I completely forgot the idea that he was with my ex and I totally got into Maiden. He played one tune after the other. We listened to the whole Power Slave album. He gave me Piece of Mind, Life after Death and Number of the Beast to take home and listened. I was hooked and there was no turning back.

Many people of my age dismiss the groups of 80s, but I have to say that it was a magical time for me and I am glad to have experienced that time period.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major.

Intro:
A (I), E (V), F# (vi)

Verse:
F# (vi), A (I), E (V), A (I), F# (vi)

Bridge:
F# (vi), G# (vii), A (I), B (ii), C# (iii)

Chorus:
F# (vi), E (V), D5 (IV5), E (V) octave higher

The lead plays over the verse and bridge progressions

A few mistakes, but you should know by now, that I record all my mistakes and in one take, minus hearing that the guitar was out of tune and starting over after tuning it.

Also, plenty of mistakes in the vocals, but I am working on it.

title: Fool for your stockings
description:
This is a ZZ Top cover from their Deguello album. I first became acquainted with ZZ Top while waiting for my friend John Price to finish practicing, so that we could play basketball. I would watch him play for hours (sometimes) to one ZZ Top song after another. Believe it or not, it was actually part of his chores that his parents set for him to do.

While this was long before the Deguello album, which was released in 1979 and I would go to that tour in 1980. I wish we had songs like this playing on the radio these days.

I have no sheet music for this song, but the intro may suggest the key of D minor.

If so then...

Verse:
A (V), F (iii)

Bridge:
Dm (i), C (vii)

Chorus:
C (vii), D6 (i), D add9 (i9)

The lead is played over the verse, bridge and chorus progressions

I spent five days trying to get all the little drum riffs, that are played in this song. Most people do not notice, because they are fixated on Billy Gibbons' awesome guitar, but this is a tough one. Normally I can get the drums and bass to be more in-synch than this, but after a while, you just have to let it go and hope that someone can pick up where you left off and you guys know that the midi is downloadable on my site. So if you can do better, by all means, have at it. One take for the guitar and vocals.

I played the first section with no pick because I can play lighter sounding songs more clean without a pick. For the second part or fool redux, I used a pick. The second part was a midi file that I downloaded long ago, hoping that it would have the bass and drums like the original, but I loved what they did so much, that I had to tack it on to the original version for complete symmetry to my journey in trying to learn how to play this one.

title: Foolin
description:
This is a Def Leppard cover and I have always been fascinated with this band. They have gone through many soul searching moments and they still come through to make our lives better.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Intro & verse:
Am9 (vi9), F(#4)/A (IV#4/vi) repeated

Bridge:
A5 (vi5), C5 (I5), G5 (V5), A5 (vi5), G5 (V5), F5 (IV5), A5 (vi5), C5 (I5), G5 (V5), A5 (vi5), E5 (iii5), F5 (IV5), G5 (V5), A5 (vi5)

Bb5/F (vii5/IV), C5/G (I5/V)

Chorus:
D C D (vii I vii), F Bb (IV vii) D C D (vii I vii), F G (IV V)

The lead is played over the chorus progression, followed by the bridge progression.

As usual all the mistakes were recorded. One take for the acoustic, one take for the guitar, one take for the front vocals and background vocals.

title: For no one
description:
This is a Beatles cover from their Revolver album. I have tried several times to learn how to play this song, but it has so far eluded me. While the verse parts are simple, the chorus is actually very difficult for me to play. I am sure that if I put some time into it, then I could get it, but the main reason why this is on the list is due to the following.

My best friend's youngest brother was going through a very tough break up that took a course of ten years to happen. When the final break up happened, as a good friend, I had to mess with him, by doing this song. When he heard the first version back in 2011, he had to call me up with laughter in his voice as he gave a big f bomb.

This is truly the best song to give a good friend a hard time, after a long awaited break up.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of B major.

Verse:
B (I), B7/A# (I7/VII), B/G# (I/vi), B/F# (I/V), Bsus4/E (Isus4/IV), C/A (ii/minor vii), B (I)

Chorus:
Inverted G#sus4 (vi sus4 (C#)), inverted G#sus4b (vi sus4b (C))

Once more, I tried a few times to record the keys. It is better that I just program the notes. The vocals took three takes.

title: For you blue
description: Not perfect but I like it "For you blue" recorded and uploaded - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=For-you-blue.mp3

title: Foxey lady
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover off of his debut album, the Jimi Hendrix Experience. A classic that is still played half a century later, what more could be said.

Without being plugged into an amp and raising the volume, then it is impossible to achieve the feedback sound, but if I plugged into my Marshall TSL 100 with four Celestion speakers within a 1969 cabinet, then my neighbors might not be too happy with me.

I know that you can hear the feedback coming, so I leave it up to your imagination.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E major, which is strange because the song is centered on the F#m7 chord, for which I will base my analysis.

Verse:
F#m7 (i7), B (IV)

Chorus:
F#m7 (i7), E (vii), B (IV)

The lead is played over the verse progression.

It took me two takes, mainly because I had my pick in my mouth and I couldn't reach the guitar to start on time. One could argue that I failed on take two, but I would say not as bad as take one.

As you know by now, I record all my mistakes.

Side note, one could argue that I did not finish the lead in time, but if you listen to the original recording, then you can hear the track with the lead fade out, as the track with the rhythm guitar begins the chorus. Since I am only recording one track, there is no way that I can play both at the same time.

I am using the CrazyTrain setting on my RP500 for this track - you can download all the settings with this sys backup file http://kronusproductions.com/song_angular/assets/downloads/RP500_backup_syx.zip

title: Freewill
description:
This is a Rush cover tune from their Permanent Waves album and I was completely enthralled as a fan by this time. It came at a time of great hope for the future. Of course, later that year both John Bonham & John Lennon past away. With that said, this was also the year that I would attend my first concert. I had opportunities to go to previous Rush concerts in the seventies, but as a child only working part time, I could not afford the whopping $17.50 price. My how times have changed. I still cannot believe that I complained about that price.

What can I say, it was literally half of my weekly paycheck working part time at the gas station. Nevertheless, I was not going to miss another tour and I saved up for a ticket and it was up to $25, which I held my tongue and took it like a man. I would love it if concert tickets were that price today.

I got into every song on this album, except their most popular song, which played on the radio all the time - Entre Nous. It's a good song, but I just didn't get into that much. I personally love Natural Science the most and, living in Houston TX at the time, Freewill was not a song that was well received, except by die hard Rush fans, such as myself.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of D major.

There are a series of notes and double stops that are played in the intro, I will break down the double stops (chords):
F (iii), G (IV), C (vii), G (IV), F (iii)
F (iii), G (IV), F (iii), C (vii), G9 (IV9)

Verse is a series of notes that match the melody:
F F C B A G, F F C E D C D E, F F C B A G, F F C E D B C G

Bridge or Pre-chorus:
Bm711 (vi7add11), Bb711 (vib711), Fsus2 (iii sus2), C (vii) I play an Fsus2 except with the E on the b string instead of the F, Bm711 (vi7add11), Bb711 (vib711), D to Dsus4 (I to I sus4)

Chorus - I simplify this section by playing:
D (I), C# (VII), A (V), B (vi), E (ii), F# (iii), A (V)
D (I), C# (VII), B (vi), A (V), G (IV), F# (iii), A (V) - I messed up every time during this recording

Interlude is a series of notes. The lead is played over a solo bass, which could be viewed as the key of F major:
F (I), Bb (IV), Eb (vii), Dm (vi)

This took me three takes on the guitar and two on the vocals, but as usual, I record all my mistakes. There are three guitar parts during the lead and I only played one of them.

title: Friends
description:
This is one of my originals that I wrote in 1976, shortly after the passing of my best friend, Dilbert Jones. I often give credit to Dilbert for most, if not, all of my lyrics. Obviously with the subject matter of this song, it is apparent that I am referring to my friend's passing and, looking back, I can not help but feel like this was his way of telling me that everything will be alright.

I used to play this song with just an acoustic guitar and I would try to explain where all the other instruments would come into play. Until I started using a sequencer in the early 90s, no one could fully grasp how full and extravagant this song actually is.

Of course, the sequencer did not do this song justice, but now with VSTs, you can hear how powerful this song can be.

Verse:
D (I), F (iii), F (iii), G (IV), A (V)

Chorus:
C (vii), D (I), E (ii), E (ii), D (I), C (vii)

The lead is played over a portion of the verse:
F (iii), G (IV), A (V)

Two takes for the lead and the vocals. As usual, all mistakes are recorded.

title: Full bug
description:
I do not know why Van Halen named this song "Full Bug" when the chorus repeats 'Best part of a man,' so I named my version 'Best part of a man,' which can be found on the list at 19 on page 1

This is one of my favorite Van Halen songs and it's too bad that I do not do a great of playing it, but I love to play it, regardless.

The album "Diver Down" gave Van Halen the first world wide number one hit and placed among the world's greatest bands, which lead to being the headliner for the US Festival in 1982.

At that point, I had been trying to tell people for years that Van Halen should be taken seriously and this was my validation.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E major.

Intro is a series of notes played with a counter point to E.

Verse:
E (I), A (IV) followed by a series notes that continues to resolve to E (I), G (iii), E (I), D (vii)

Bridge:
A7 (IV7), E7 (I7)

Chorus:
D7 (vii7) played twice, B7 (V7) to Bdim (v) to B5 (V5)

The guitar lead is played over E7 (I7) and the harmonica is played over the bridge and chorus progressions.

Two takes for the guitar and two takes with the vocals, with a handful of punch ins (for timing purposes).

The harmonica solo isn't perfect but it's what I could figure out and hopefully someone can take it to the next level.

title: Funeral for a friend
description:
This is an Elton John cover and it is the longest song in my toolkit. I have just learned this song and I have used Variaudio plugin to correct my vocal mistakes or to at least make it palatable. 

When I first heard this song, way back when, because of it's long intro, I did not know what band was playing, but I remember saying to my friend, 'this band is going to be huge,' for which he replied, 'they already are.' He went on to inform me that it was Elton John.

I was hoping that this song marked a new direction of long, thematically type of songs for the band, like many bands did in the 70s, but it did not turn out this way.

Since this song is so long and I do not have the sheet music for this song, I will only analyze the verse & chorus progressions.

I will assume that it is in the key of A minor, because many parts start and end on A and the G is not sharp. However, F# is played later on which throws off my analysis.

Intro to verse:
F F G E A

Verse:
A (i), E (V), A (i), D (IV), Bm7/A (ii7/I), Bm (ii), A (i), F#m (vi), Bm (ii) C (iii) D (IV)

Interlude:
A (i), E (V), D (IV), D7 (IV7)

Chorus:
F#m (vi), Bm7/A (ii7/I), E sus4/E (V sus4/V)

Bridge:
A (i), Bm7/A (ii7/I), C#m7 (iii#7), D (IV), Am7 (i7), F#m (vi), E (V)

One take for guitar and one take for vocals - keep in mind that the Variaudio plugin is correcting my vocals.

Whomever made the midi file that I found, way back when, thank you. You saved me a lot of work.

title: Gas station man
description:
This is an original song that I wrote in the early 80s when I was the night manager to a Gulf gas station that was on the corner of South Braeswood Blvd and Linkwood Dr.

At the time, what they called "the great recession" and gas prices sky rocketed, which left me on the side of the bad guy with plenty of people upset at me. Sounds like a great time to write some lyrics.

While Stevie Ray Vaughn had not yet come to my attention, I was trying to write a Hendrix like song, comparative to the kinds of things he was experimenting with before his passing, like the saxophone intro to Rainy Day Dream Away

Of course, I am recording this song with the knowledge of the Stevie Ray Vaughn sound and I used it for this song.

It is a basic blues progression that repeats, like Hendrix, I jazz it up by playing 7th chords over their respective tonics.

Verse:
E (I), A (IV), E (I), A (IV), E (I)

Chorus:
G (iii), B (V)

Bridge (turnaround):
E (I), A (IV), B (V)

Two takes on the vocals and one take on the guitar

title: Get Back
description:
This is a Beatles cover and I first heard this song in the early seventies. Along with many other fans, we were still hoping for a Beatles reunion. Of sorts, there are many times that all four members played on Ringo's albums but due to contractual obligations, they were not allowed to play all four together. Thought I would share that if anyone is interested.

As with many great rock songs, it follows a kind of blues progression in the key of A major.

Intro:
A (I), G (vii), D (IV)

Verse:
A (I), D (IV), A (I)

Chorus:
A (I), A7 (I7), D (IV), G (vii), D (IV)

The leads are played over the verse progression.

When I used to practice keys at least an hour or two a day, my fingers were stronger, but since I do not do that any more, I had to push up the velocity of the notes for the key board solo. I practiced for a week, but what once was, would not return. With that said, I was able to record it in one take.

The guitar took three takes, mainly because the volume needed adjusting but I also mistimed the playing of the G to D, as well. As a result, I turned on the distortion for the third lead, so that you could hear it more clearly.

title: Girls got rhythym
description:
This is an AC/DC cover song and I first heard this song 1979 for their debut album "Highway to Hell" I was in tenth grade and this song was perfect for my state of mind, at the time.

Out of all the sheet music that I have, this is one of the few that I do not. However, since most of the song is played with some form of a D chord, then I am going to guess that it is in the key of D major.

Intro, Verse & Chorus:
D (I), G5 (IV5), A (V), A6 (V6), A (V), A7 (V7), A (V) - repeat until last three measures and change the G5 to D sus4 (I sus4)

Bridge:
B (vi), E (vii)

Two takes for the guitar and vocals. As usual, I record all my mistakes, which includes the guitars are slightly out of tune.

title: Glass onion
description:
This is a Beatles cover and I first heard this song in the early 70s. On the white album, it comes after Dear Prudence. It's almost hard to believe that a group of guys could just crank out the jams like they did, way back when.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Verse:
Am (vi), F7 (IV7), Am (vi), F7 (IV7), Am (vi), Gm7 (v7), C7 (I7), Gm7 (v7), C7 (I7), Gm7 (v7)

Bridge:
F7 (IV7), D7 (ii7), F7 (IV7), D7 (ii7), F7 (IV7)

Chorus:
F7 (IV7), G7 (V7)

Violin instrumental section:
Am (vi) - I play an A major, F/A (IV/vi), D7/A (ii7/vi), Am7 (vi7) - I play an A major, followed by the chorus progression

Outro violins go from F7 (IV7) to D7 (ii7)

One take for the guitar and seven takes for the vocals. For some reason, the recording did not pick up the lower guitar strings, but it sounds better that way and, as usual, I record all my mistakes.

title: Gonna win d lotto
description:
This is a Def Leppard cover and it brings back memories of early 80s, when MTV was just starting and the hope of any band could make it.

I have taken the song "Bringing on the heartbreak" and changed parts of it to be "Gonna win d lotto". Little bit of sloppy playing at the beginning, but not bad for a first take.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of C major. You can see by the tabs and midi that there are no chords played during the intro.

Verse:
Am (vi), G6 (V6), F6 (IV6), Fmaj7(6) (IVmaj7(6)), Bb/B (vii/VII), E7 (iii7)

Bridge:
C5 (I5), D5 C5 (ii5) (I5), G5 (V5)
D5 (ii5), E5 D5 (iii5) (ii5), B5 (VII5)
C5 (I5), G5 (V5) repeated four times

Chorus:
A5 (vi5), F5 (IV5), G5 (V5) repeated four times

The guitar solos are played over the verse progressions.

title: Goodbye Yellowbrick Road
description:
This is an Elton John cover and I first heard this song in the early 70s. Back then, it seemed like every other song that he recorded was souring up the charts.

Obviously, I love Elton John and his songs touch my heart as no other artist has and that includes the Beatles, Elvis & Rush, which are my top three of all time.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of F major.

Intro:
F (I), C/E (V/VII), Dm (vi), Dm/C (vi/V), Bb (IV), Bb/C (IV/V)

Verse:
Gm7 (ii7), Bb (IV), C (V), F (I), F/A (I/iii), Bb (IV), Eb (vii), C (V), F (I) - repeat

Bridge:
Bbm7 (iv7), Eb (vii), Ab (iiib), Db (vib), Bbm7 (iv7), C (V) - circle of fourths (first four chords)

Chorus:
F (I), A (iii), Bb (IV), 
F (I), D (vi), Gm (ii), C (V),
F (I), C/E (V/VII), Dm (vi), 
A (iii), Bb (IV), Db (vib)

Followed by intro and bridge progressions, ending on F (I)

Vocals took seven takes and keys only one take (technically I double clicked on the record button, so the file will have "2" in the name)

Recorded all mistakes as usual and I hope you enjoy

title: Goodness is gone
description:
This is an original song that was written in three different decades. The first section was written in the late 70s. The second section (music) in the 90s and the lyrics in 2011.

This is being recorded a day after attending services for my good friend, Buddy Smith, rest in peace brother. Back in '87, he told me that I should pursue my music dream and go to California, which I did. I often wonder how my life would have gone, had he not believed in me so much. While I meet a lot ARs in Cali ('87-'88), I was stubborn and it kept me from signing a deal. I would return to Texas after spending most of '88 in NYC and continued to understand music theory, instead of just finding things while improvising. This one is dedicated to Buddy, I will always cherish all the good times that we had. You are a one of kind and thank you for your support.

I can remember playing at Willies Pub (Rice University) in '86 and there were two people in the bar besides my bass player and myself (one of those two people was the bartender). During the third song of the set, I was jamming my ass off and I was so angry that no one was there to enjoy it or witness it. When I finished playing, there were all these applause and cheering. I looked up and Buddy had brought about twelve to fifteen people with him and he was leading the cheers with whistles and all. A true friend.

This song is combining three styles of music - Hendrix, Stevie Ray Vaughn and the Beatles.

The first section is played in the key of C major and the second section is played in the key of E major.

Intro:
F(IV), G (V), A (vi) - repeat
A (vi), D (ii), E (iii) - repeat 4 times

Verse:
C7 (I7), E7 (III7), Am (vi), F7 (IV7), C7 (I7), E7(III7) - it should be Em7, but I was a kid when I wrote this part

Chorus:
A (VI), G (V), F (IV), G (V), A (VI) - it should be Am

Second part of the song is basically a twelve bar blues section with three interludes, just like the Beatles "Yer Blues" and so many other classic blues songs.

Verse:
A7 (IV7), E7 (I7) 

Chorus:
G (iii), B (V)

Bridge:
E(I), A (IV), B(V)

Interlude:
B(V), E (I)

The lead is played over the twelve bar blues progression and I combine Hendrix and Stevie Ray Vaughn licks in an E major pentatonic scale.

Some timing issues in the beginning, not bad for two takes on guitar. Two takes for vocals with seven punch ins (timing) and a crackling noise that just comes from nowhere. I suspect that there is some kind of a spike in power and my power strip is supposed to handle this, but I cannot afford to spend any more on this project - oh well.
 
Recorded all mistakes as usual and I hope you enjoy

title: Green Manalishi
description:
This is a Judas Priest song and I first heard this song in 1976. I can remember sitting there listening to this two awesome guitarist sharing guitar licks. 

Since I do not have the official sheet music, I am going to take a guess that the song is played in the key of E major.

Intro:
E (I), D (vii), E (I), G (iii), E (I), D (vii), C (vi), B (V), C (vi)

Verse:
E (I), G (iii), A (IV)

Chorus:
G (iii), A (IV)

Bridge:
E (I), D (vii), E (I), DDE (vii vii I), E (I), D (vii), E (I), GGE (iii iii I) - repeat twice

The lead is played over the intro progression.

Some timing issues in the beginning and the lead, not bad for one take on guitar and one take on vocals.
 
Recorded all mistakes as usual and I hope you enjoy

title: Guess thats why they call it d blues
description:
This is an Elton John cover and I heard this song in the 80s. I remember it was in a regular rotation on MTV, just around the same time that my high school girlfriend was calling it quits. Ironically, she would pick my friend, whom I just went to his service to lay him to rest this past Saturday. It is funny how life brings us back to memories that were so long ago.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major. Although you would think that with all references to G, that it would be in G. Oh well

Intro:
C (I), E (iii), F (IV) - repeat

Verse:
G (V), Em7 (iii7), F (IV), C (I), F (IV) - repeat C to F three times and end on C
G (V), Bm7 (vii7), F (IV), C (I), F (IV) - repeat C to F three times and end on C

Bridge:
G (V), B7 (VII7), Em (iii), Dm (ii), C (I)
G (V), Am (vi), F (IV), G (V) - turn around riff - Am7 (vi7), G/B (V/vii)

Chorus:
C (I), G/B (V/vii), F (IV)
C (I), G/B (V/vii), F (IV)
C/E (I/iii), G (V), Am (vi)
C/E (I/iii), F (IV), D7/F# (ii7/IV#)
F (IV), F/G (IV/V)

The harmonica solo is played over the verse progression.

Some timing issues in the beginning and, not bad for one take on keys and one take on vocals. Once more, since I do not practice keys, like I used to, my fingers are not producing enough velocity. Full disclosure, I had to add 20 to the velocity across the whole keyboard track.
 
Recorded all mistakes as usual and that includes the little crackle sound that happens from time to time, when I record the vocals. I hope you enjoy

title: Gypsy eyes
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover from the Electric Ladyland album, which is named after the studio that Hendrix and the Eddie Kramer built together. The studio is still being used today.

That is right, the same Eddie Kramer that would design a guitar that Eddie Van Halen would later use. I first heard this song in high school, when a classmate of mine who was a Hendrix fanatic, told me that Hendrix is more than just Purple Haze, Fire, etc...

I am glad that I met you Lee Boulden (I think I remember that correctly), because who knows where my musical tastes would be now.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of C major.

There are no chord progressions to speak of and the song is made up of patterns of notes. All I can really write about, is that these patterns of notes are all played within the A minor pentatonic scale.

There are three guitar tracks (one could say four tracks with the muted rhythmic track being the forth) and I am only playing one of them. Keep in mind, that this song is actually played in a half-step down in tuning.

Nevertheless, here's the way that I would break it down. 

Intro:
A5 (vi5)

Verse:
C (I), D (ii), A5 (vi5)

Yep, that is it. You can download the midi for the specific.

Recorded all mistakes as usual. One take on the guitar track and one take on the vocals.

title: Hangem high
description:
This is a Van Halen cover off of their Diver Down and this is one of my favorite Van Halen songs. I first heard it when it came out around my birthday in April 1982 (senior year).

When this album came out, it gave Van Halen their first number one album on the charts and they were made the headliners at the US Festival. I had been telling people how great of a band they were and this was validation for me.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major.

Intro:
A/B (IV/V), A/E (IV/I)

Verse:
D (vii), E (I), D (vii), B (V), A (IV)

Chorus:
D (vii), C (vib), E (I), E/D# (I/VII), D (vii), C (vib)

Bridge:
C#m (vi), F# (ii), E (I), D (vii), A (IV), C#m (vi), C (vib), D (vii), E (I)

The lead is played over the following progression:
B (V), A (IV), C (vib), G (iii)
D (vii), E (I) repeat twice
D (vii), A (IV), E (I) repeat four times and end with F# (ii)

Timing mess up at the beginning and at the beginning & end of the lead, but that did not stop from recording it.

Recorded all mistakes as usual. One take on the guitar track and one take on the vocals. I had to add two decibals of gain the vocals during the verse section.

title: Happy Birthday
description:
This is a song that was written by Patty and Mildred Hill and I created the midi file with this version/composition for my sister (Abeer) in the early 90s. At the time, I had just been laid off, going through a divorce, etc... and I told her that I did not have any money to buy her a birthday present, but I made this for her.

She would hugged me and told me that this was the best present that anyone had ever given to her. I still makes fills my eyes with a few tears (good ones), when I think about it.

While the sheet music that I have for this song is in some box somewhere, I would say that this is in the key of C major.

The composition is based on the melody of the song and treating them as if they were chords.

G (V), G (V), A (vi), G (V), C (I), B (vii)
G (V), G (V), A (vi), G (V), D (ii), C (I)
G (V), G (V), G (V - octave above), E (iii), D (ii), C (I), B (vii)
A/F (vi/IV), F (IV), C/E (I/iii), C (I), D (ii), C (I)

If you look at the progressions closely, then you should see that this is classic Beethoven. 

I programmed all the instruments, which means there is no live performance of myself in this video and no mistakes :-)

title: Hard days night
description:
This is a Beatles cover from their early years, when Beatlemania was so immense that it over shadowed the Vietnam war.

Recorded all mistakes as usual. One take on the guitar track and one take on the vocals. I used an old trick, where I double the vocal tracks and offset the clean vocals by a smidgen

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major.

Intro:
A7 (ii7)

Verse:
G (I), C7 (IV7), G (I), F (vii)

Chorus:
I play a series of notes in the G major scale, which correspond to the melody, but you can play a G chord here (I)

Bridge:
Bm (iii), Em (vi), Bm (iii), G (I), Em (vi), C7 (IV7), D7 (V7)

The lead is played over the verse progression.

Since I am using the Fishman Triple Play to connect to the Ample Sound's AMG2 VST, I am able to correct the velocity of certain notes throughout the song.

One take for the guitar and vocals, with very few mistakes.

title: Heard it on d X
description:
This is a ZZ Top cover that I "heard it" back in the mid 70s. Fandago is one of my favorite ZZ Top albums. Ironically, Frank Beard and I worked for the same man, William Lawson "Bud" Smith.
