He said to me one day on the job, "I am going to tell you the same thing that I told Frank, 'you better be better at music, than you are at construction'"

That gave me a lot of fuel to move towards music and Lawson's middle son William Lawson "Buddy" Smith II, was the one that encouraged me to go to Los Angeles in '87. Who knows what I would have done had those two not pushed me in this direction and thank both of them. Rest in peace my compadres.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major.

Intro & verse:
A (vi), C (I), A (vi), G (V)

Bridge:
D (ii), F (IV), D (ii), E (iii), G (V), E (iii)

Chorus:
C (I), G (V) - repeat three times and end on A (vi)

The lead is played over the three progressions.

I recorded the guitar track twice (once using the Fishman Triple Play and the other using the RP-500). Vocals two tracks, the first had too many distortion peaks.

As usual, I record all my mistakes.

title: Heartbreaker
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover that I heard in the early 70s. While I didn't appreciate how great of guitarist that Jimmy Page is, at the time, I can tell you now that I have a new found sense of wonderment as to how great he actually is. 

Some guitarist have speed and some have style, but to have both, is a rare quality. Until you actually try to play a Jimmy Page guitar part, you cannot understand just how great it is.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major.

Intro:
A (I), B (ii), A (I)

Verse:
A (I), D to A (IV to I)

Bridge:
C (vi), D (IV), E (V)

Yeah, when you break it down, it's just a blues progression.

The guitar track took two takes, as well as the vocals.

As usual, I record all my mistakes.

title: Heartless
description:
This is a Heart cover and I first heard this in and around '77. I thought it was the most complete song. I remember I had wished that I could make songs just like that.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major.

Intro:
A9 (ii9), G6 (I6), Em9 (vi9)

Verse:
This should be played in Em7 (vi7) blues rhythm riff, but I play an A5 (ii5)

Bridge:
G6 (I6), A9 (ii9)

Chorus:
Em (vi), E5 F5 F#5 G5 (vi vii VII I), C (IV), C B Bb A (IV III iii ii), (I finish with an A5 chord)
G C# B F# F (I IV# III VII vii), E (vi) finish with repeating the intro progression

Interlude:
Em9 (vi9), A7 A7sus2 A7sus4 A7 (ii7 ii7 sus2 ii7 sus4 ii7) - later this changes to A6 (ii6)

The guitar track took three takes, as well as the vocals.

As usual, I record all my mistakes.

title: Here comes d Sun
description:
This is a Beatles cover that I heard around '73 and knew that it was the Beatles. I had not known who did this song until my uncle purchased the double album 1967-1970

George Harrison has some of my favorite Beatle songs and this is one of them. I wish the group had moved more towards making these kind of songs, like this one and Something.

However, they did pretty good ;-)

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major

Intro:
D (IV), G (vii), A7 (I7), D (IV)

Verse:
D (IV), G (vii), A7 (I7), D (IV)

Chorus:
D (IV), G (vii), E7 (V7), D (IV), G (vii), Em7 (v7), D (IV), A (I)

Interlude:
A7 (I7), C (iii), G (vii), D (IV)

This song is played with the capo on the seventh fret, but I play it without a capo

One take for the vocals and guitar. I tried to use the Fishman Triple play but it could not keep up with the faster notes. I am telling you that this guitar track is not as easy as it sounds like it is.

As usual, I record all my mistakes, but they were very few. Sorry that I am not able to pick the lower strings as well as the higher strings.

Maybe one day when I can afford a real sound engineer in a real studio.

title: Hey Joe
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover that I heard in the mid 70s. While I thought that there was nothing special about the studio version, I loved the live version, which I heard in 1979-80.

I have tried to incorporate the live licks with the studio version drums & bass. When I programmed this song in the early 90s, I added two verse sections before the lead. As a result, I have switched the lyrics to accomodate for the two extra verses. Also, I added one extra progression during the lead, which was compensated by extending the lead (improv).

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major.

Intro:
E (vi)

Verse:
C (IV), G (I), D (V), A (ii), E (vi) - classic pop rock progression

Three takes for the guitar (first take technical issue, second take I started playing the lead where it should be, but see above note). Vocals one take.

As always, I record my mistakes

title: Hey Jude
description:
This is a Beatles cover I cannot remember when I first heard this song - sometime in the early 70s and I did not know who sang the song, until my uncle purchased a 1967-1970 double album in 1973.

When I listened to the double album, I remember recognizing all the songs and I could not believe that one group had made all these songs. Of course, I became inthralled with the band and I would soon find out, that this was just the tip of the iceberg.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of F major.

Verse:
F (I), C (V), C7 (V7), C7sus4 (V7 sus4), F (I), Bb (IV), F (I), C7 (V7) - that is classical Beethoven.

Bridge:
F7 (I7), Bb (IV), Bb/A (IV/iii), Gm (ii), Gm7/F (ii7/I), C7/E (V7/VII), C7 (V7), F (I)

Chorus:
F (I), Eb (vii), Bb (IV), F (I)

I end the song with F (I), A (iii), C (V), F (I)

As always, I record my mistakes - timing issues at the beginning, the one thing that a computer cannot give you and that is band mates that know when to begin based on your bad tempo :-)

title: Highway to hell
description:
This is an AC/DC cover from their album, which came out in 1979-80. When I heard this song, it lead to me listening to the rest of the album and I loved them from the beginning. 

If ever there was a love at first site for me, then this was the case. I would learn how to play this song in 2010 - never too late.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is in the key of A major.

Intro & Verse:
A (I), F#/D G (vi/IV vii) - repeat three times - G A (vii I)

Chorus:
A (I), D (IV), G D A (vii IV I) 

Interlude before the lead:
D Dsus4 

The lead is played over A 

As always, I record my mistakes - timing issues at the beginning. One take for guitar and vocals.

title: Home sweet home
description: Song number 208 - the guitar track was fun to record "Home sweet home" - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Home-sweet-home.mp3

title: Honey Pie
description:
This is a Beatles cover from their "white" album and I first heard this song in mid 70s, after purchasing the "white" album.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major.

Intro:
Em (vi), A6 (ii6), Am/D (ii/V), Cm (iv), G (I) - repeat
A7 (ii7), D7 (V7)

Verse:
G (I), Eb7 (vib7), E7 (vi7), A7 (ii7), D7 (V7)

Chorus:
G (I), F# (VII), F (vii)
Em (vi), C#m7 (iv#7), G (I), G7 (I7), C (IV), E7/B (vi7/iii - I play G/B), Am (ii), D7 (V7)

Mistakes recorded as usual, one take for the keys and two takes for the vocals

title: Honkey cat
description:
This is an Elton John cover and I first heard this song in the 70s. Before I knew who the Beatles and Elvis were, Elton John was my favorite. Since he was on the charts all the time, as a child I could just listen to the radio and catch an Elton song somewhere.

He was the first very popular caucasian musician that I saw appear on Soul Train and it wasn't for this song. Although, that would have been hilarious. 

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major.

Intro & Verse:
D7 (V7 with an added 6), G (I) - I switch from G to E

Chorus:
B7 (iii7), E (VI), D (V), G (I)

One take for both keys and vocals - as usual, all mistakes were recorded

title: Hotel Cali
description:
This is an Eagles cover and I first heard this in the early 70s. It is one of the many reasons why I wanted to grow up in California and why I took a chance to move there in '87-88.

While I would return again in 2002-2014, I still think about it everyday and I can relate to the lyric, "you check out any time you like, but you can never leave"

In this cover, I am combining their acoustic version with the studio version.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of D major.

Intro and verse:
Bm (vi), F# (III), Asus2 (V sus2), E9 (ii9), G (IV), D (I), Em7 (ii7), F# (III) - I play the F# without the F# in the root

Chorus:
G (IV), D (I), F# (III), Bm (vi), G (IV), D (I), F# (III), Em7 (ii7)

One take on the acoustic guitar, one take on the lead guitar and three takes on the vocals

As usual, I record all my mistakes

title: I me me mine
description:
This is a Beatles cover and I heard this song sometime in the mid 70s. I would later see the "Let it be" sessions movie, where you could actually see them piece together songs and this was one of them. To watch the maturation of this song gave me confidence that I could put songs together, little by little.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A minor.

Intro:
Am (i)

Verse:
Am (i), D7 (IV7), G (vii), E (V), Am (i)

Bridge:
Dm (iv), E7b9 (V7b9), E/B (V/ii)

Interlude:
Am (i), Am7b (i7b), Am7 (i7), Am6 (i6), F7b (vib7b) - I muted out this chord, for some reason, it just did not sound right to me - maybe my guitar was out of tune

Chorus - blues rhythm 
A (i), D (IV), E7 (V7)

I used the Fishman Triple play via the Ample Sound AGM2 vst for the acoustic part (a lot of post production clean up)

One take on the acoustic guitar, two takes on the lead guitar and three takes on the vocals

As usual, I record all my mistakes

title: I wanna b yr man
description:
This is a Beatles cover and, even though this was one of their earliest recordings, I did not hear it until I bought an album titled "Rock n Roll music" in the mid 80s.

This would lead me to truly falling in love with the fab four more than ever before. 

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major.

Verse:
E7 (I7)

Chorus:
F#7 (ii7), B7 (V7), E (I), C#7 (vi7), F#7 (ii7), B7 (V7), E (I)

The lead is played over E7.

One take for the keys and guitar. Two takes on the main vocals and one take on the background vocals.

title: Ice cream man
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their debut album, that I heard in '78 and I fell in love with every song on the album. At the time, I was into Ted Nugent and, ironically, Van Halen was opening for him.

I recorded with my Ovation, but as you know by now, I was unable to get the lower strings to be recorded well. As a result, I used the Fishman Triple Play system to connect to Ample Sound's AGM2 vst, with a little post production clean up work.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major and it follows standard blues progressions.

Verse:
E (I), A (IV), E (I), A (IV), E (I), B (V), A (IV), E (I) - are blues Beethoven or what? I mean look at that, tonic to sub-dominant, to tonic, to sub-dominant, to tonic, to dominant, to sub-dominant, to tonic - that's Beethoven.

Two takes on acoustic, four takes with the combination of (two with Fishman (acoustic) and two with the Ibanez) and two takes with the vocals

As usual I record all my mistakes, unless there is a technical glitch, as there seems to always be. It is perplexing to me that every recording has to have a glitch. Otherwise, most recordings would be one take.

title: If u take yr whisky home
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their "Women and Children first" album and I love the sound of Eddie on acoustic guitar, mixed with the electric, and having a blues based progression makes my heart love it even more.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of Bb major and the guitar solos switch to the key of D major, which is the third of Bb

Intro:
Gm7 (vi7)

Verse:
Gm7 (vi7)

Chorus:
Am7 (vii7)

While the lead is in the key of D major, it is played over B (vi) chord

The outro is played over a Dm progression and ends on a D major, but I play a G major

Once more, I record all my mistakes, unless there is a technical glitch, as there seems to always be. It is perplexing to me that every recording has to have a glitch. Otherwise, most recordings would be one take.

title: Im not perfect
description:
This is a KRONUS Productions (me) original and I wrote this in 2003. Due to many tragic events, including the passing of my Mother, I would eventually do the first recording in 2007 and another in 2011, shortly after Carol's passing.

According to the sheet music in my head :-), this song is played in the key of C major

Verse:
G (V), C (I), G (V), C (I), F (IV), C (I), F (IV)

Chorus:
E (iii), F# (IV#), G (V)

Bridge:
Asus7 (vi sus7), Bbsus7 (vii sus7) - repeat four times and end with chorus progression

Four takes on the guitar, but I believe I have the best acoustic recording thus far. Two takes on vocals and one take on backup vocals

As usual are mistakes are recorded

title: Im on fire
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their debut album and I loved it from the first time that I heard it.

Obviously my equipment does not pick up all the notes the way a professional recording studio would, but I still love playing it.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major - yeah, surprising to me as well

Intro:
E (vi), D (V), C (IV), D (V), B (iii) - repeat twice

Verse:
Em (vi), D (V), Em (vi), A (ii)
Em (vi), D (V), Em (vi), G/D (I/V) - repeat 

Pre-Chorus:
F# (vii), G (I) - repeat twice
D6 (V6), C# (IV#), D (V)

Chorus:
G/E (I/vi), D/E (V/vi), A/E (ii/vi)

Bridge:
F# (vii), G (I), Csus2 (IV sus2), Bsus2 (iii sus2)

Lead is played over the bridge progression/

Five takes for the guitar track and one take for both the lead and background vocals.

As usual are mistakes are recorded

title: Im only sleeping
description:
This is a Beatles cover and my sister has often said that this is her anthem.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of Eb minor, which I play in the key of Em (I do not want to tune my guitar down by half a step)

Verse:
Em (i), Am (iv), G (III), C (vib), G (III), B7 (V7)
Em (i), Am (iv), G (III), C (vib), G (III), C (vib)

Bridge:
G (III), Am (iv), Bm (v), Am (iv), C (vib), Em (i)

Chorus:
D7 (vii7), E7 (I7), Am (iv), Amsus4 (iv sus4), D7 (vii7)

The lead is played over the verse progression.

Three takes on vocals and two takes on the guitar.

As usual are mistakes are recorded

title: Im the one
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their debut album and, if I had to choose one song, then this would be my favorite Van Halen song.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of C major.

Much of this song is played without chords, which includes the intro, verse and lead sections. The intro is played over Am (vi) bass tones, while the second interlude starts over Gm (v) and ends on Am (vi) bass tones.
The verse is played over Am (vi) bass tones.

With that said, the pre-chorus is a series descending chromatic progressions:
A (vi), Ab (vib), G (V), F# (IV#), F (IV), E (iii), D (ii) - repeat
B (vii), Bb (viib), A (vi), Ab (vib), G (V), F# (IV#), F (IV), E (iii) - repeat

Chorus:
C (I), D (ii), E (iii) - repeat four times

The lead is played over Bm (vii) bass tones

After the vocal interlude, a chromatic ascending diminished progression:
A (vi), A# (vi#), B (vii), C (i), C# (i#), D (ii), D# (ii#)

Outro is played over E (iii)

Two takes on the guitar, three takes on vocals and, as usual, all mistakes are recorded.

title: Imagine
description:
This is a John Lennon cover and, believe it or not, while I heard this song from time to time, I did not know it was John Lennon until after he passed away.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major

Verse:
C (I), C7 (I7), F (IV)

Bridge:
F (IV), Am/E (vi/iii), Dm7 (ii7), Dm7/C (ii7/I), G (V), C/G (I/V), G7 (V7)

Chorus:
F (IV), G (V), C (I), C7 (I7), E (iii), E7 (iii7) - repeat three times
F (IV), G (V), C (I)

If you look at this song, as with so many classics, then you will see Beethoven

Two takes on the keys (post clean up work on the midi) and two takes on the vocals

As usual are mistakes are recorded

title: Immigrant song
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover and I heard this in the early 70s, where I could easily identify with the content, as our family were immigrants living in Houston from 1969

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of A major.

Intro:
F# (vi)

Verse:
A -> E (I V), E -> A -> F# (V I vi) - repeat twice 

Chorus:
A (I), B (ii), C (iii)

Outro:
F# (vi), C# (III)

One take on the guitar and vocal tracks (made post timing adjustments for the vocals)

As usual are mistakes are recorded

title: In my life
description:
This is a Beatles cover and it is also Carol's favorite (RIP my friend)

I first heard this song in the early 70s, when I bought the Beatles 1962-66 double album.

According to the sheet music that I have, it is played in the key of A major.

Intro:
A (I), E (V) - repeat

Verse:
A (I), E7 (V7), F#m (vi), G (viib), D (IV), Dm (iv), A (I)
A (I), E (V), F#m (vi), G (viib), D (IV), Dm (iv), A (I)

Bridge:
F#m (vi), D (IV)

Chorus:
G (viib), A (I)

Bridge2:
F#m (vi), B7 (ii7)

Chorus2:
Dm7

The harpsichord lead is played over the verse progression.

One take on the guitar, using Fishman Triple Play via EW's Fab Four vst (Ticket to Guitar) along with Guitar Rig's Jazz Amp, and vocal tracks (made post timing adjustments for the vocals)

As usual are mistakes are recorded

title: In the end
description:
These are Beatles' covers - Golden Slumbers, Carry that weight and In the end, which I heard when I purchased their "Abbey Road" album. Most people think this was their last album. It was their last released album and "Let it be" was actually the last album recorded together.

According to the sheet music that I have, the songs are played in the following keys:

Golden Slumbers - C major 

Verse:
Am7 (vi7), G7 (V7), C (I) - I play Am (vi), E7 (iii7), Am (vi), Dm7 (ii7) - I play F (IV), G (V)

Bridge - "Golden slummbers..."
C (I), Fadd9 (IV add9)

Carry that weight - C major:
Verse:
C (I), G7 (V7)

Bridge & Interlude:
F7 (IV7), Bm7-5 (VII7 -5), E7 (iii7) - followed by interlude
Am7 (vi7), Am7/D (vi7/ii), Dm7 (ii7) - I play Am (vi), G7 (V7)

After playing the verse once more, end with:
C (I), G/B (V/VII), A (vi) - repeat

In the end - A major
Verse:
A to D (I to IV), B to E (ii to V) - chromatic run A to D

Lead is played over:
A (I), D (IV)

Outro:
Am (i), G (vii), F (vib), Em (v), D (iv), C (iii)

Change to the key of C major
C (I), D/C (ii/I), Eb (iiib), F (IV), C (I)

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Iron Man
description:
This is a Black Sabbath cover, that I first heard somewhere around 1976, when a friend of mine let me hear "We sold our souls for rock 'n roll"

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of D major - I would have never have guessed

Intro:
E (ii) down to a D (I)

Verse:
B (vi), D (I), E (ii), F# to G (iii to IV) - repeat three times - D (I), E (ii)

Chorus:
E (ii), D (I), B (vi)

See sheet music for individual notes in each section

The first lead is played in the key of E major and the second returns to the key of D major

Four takes for the guitar, three takes on the lead vocals and two take on the background vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Island Girl
description:
This is an Elton John cover and I cannot remember when I downloaded the midi file for this song, but whomever made the midi file, you did an awesome job

I do not have sheet music for this song and, therefore, I do not play any instruments nor can I say what key it is played

With that said, this song was written at a time, where some of it's content is now considered politically incorrect and, as a result, I have changed some of the lyrics.

What did I do - I transformed the midi tracks to virtual instrument tracks, along with creating all the sends and groups, which lead to all the mixing

Five takes on the lead vocals and two takes on the background vocals

Hope you enjoy

title: It wont b long
description:
This is a Beatles cover that I heard in the early 70s, while watching the fab four's cartoons on Saturday mornings.

Needless to say, that I fell in love with this song and it continues to be one of favorites.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major.

Intro:
C#m (vi), E (I), C#m (vi), A (IV), A9b (I9b)

Verse:
E (I), C (vib), E (I)

Chorus:
Same as the intro

Bridge:
E (I), D#+ (VII+), D6 (vii), C#7 (vi), A (IV), B (V), F#m7 (ii7), B7 (V7)

Two takes for the guitar and five takes for the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Its so easy
description:
This is a Guns n' Roses cover and I first heard this in '87, when I was living in LA. I fell in love with the entire debut album "Appetite for destruction"

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major.

Intro:
Open E over D to E (vi over V to vi)

Verse:
Bb (iii), A (ii), G (I), E (vi)

Bridge:
A (ii), G (I), A (ii), Bb (iii), E (vi), Esus4 (vi sus4) repeat three times

Chorus:
D/F# (V/vii), G (I), Baddb6(III b6), A (ii)

The leads are played over the verse progressions.

Two takes on guitar (you should be able to see how I have to fiddle with my volume, that is one of the technical glitches that I refer to) and four takes on the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Jacobs ladder
description:
This is a Rush cover and I first heard this back in 1980, when Permanent Waves album came out

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major

Intro:
C (I), Ab (vib), F (IV), G (V), Ab (vib), E (iii)

Verse 1:
C (I), Ab (vib), Bb (viib), F (IV), Db (iib), Eb (iiib)
C (I), C# (I#), C (I)
Eb (iiib), Db (iib), F (IV)
Eb (iiib), Db (iib), C (I)
F (IV), G (V), Ab (vib)

Instrumental 1:
Bm7 (vii7), C (I), F# (IV#), G (V), A (vi)

The lead is played over the aforementioned instrumental progression

Single notes are used for the three remaining sections - see midi file for specifics

Two takes for the guitar and eleven takes for the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Jamies Cryin
description:
This is a Van Halen cover off of their debut album and I heard it when the album came out.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major

Intro, Outro & lead:
The leads are played over an E9 (I9)

Verse & Chorus:
notes played over an E9 (I9) - see my notes for the notes - Ah!

Interlude:
F#m (ii), Bm (v), A (IV)

Bridge:
C#m (vi), D (vii), C#m (vi), F# (ii), C#m (vi), D (vii)

One take for the guitar and two takes on vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Jesus just left chicago
description:
This is a ZZ Top cover that I first heard in the early 70s, maybe 74 and I love it. My friend, John Price, would practice ZZ Top songs everyday and, while I had not started playing yet, I would watch intently as he practiced. I guess I learned a thing or two.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major - what? Yep, that is what it says - one sharp

Verse:
G (I), C/G (IV/I) - repeat, C (IV), F/C (vii/IV) - repeat

Chorus:
A (ii), C (IV), G (I)

Believe it or not, that is it.

One take for the guitar and four takes on vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Johnny b good
description:
This is a Chuck Berry cover and I mixed in a little Jimi Hendrix version. Just in case you were wondering, why is playing long after the song is complete, it is because I am adding in the Hendrix version, but of course, no feedback so why bother - because I want to :-)

I do not have sheet music for this song, but I would guess that it is played in the key of A major, while Hendrix mixes minor pentatonic scales over the major progressions that he is playing over

Intro, interludes and chorus:
A (I)

Verse:
A (I) repeat three times then once to D (IV) and return to A (I)

Pre-chorus:
E (V), A (I)

This is a standard blues progression played over a Pentecostal back beat

Two takes for the guitar and one take on vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Just d way u r
description:
This is a Billy Joel cover from his "The Stranger" album in 1977 and I loved it from the moment that I heard it

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of D major

Intro & interlude:
Bm6/D (vi6/I), Bm/D (vi/I)

Verse:
D (I), Bm6 (vi6), G7 (IV7), Bm (vi), D7 (I7), G7 (IV7), Gm7 (iv7), D/F# (I/iii), Am7 (v7), D7 (I7), G7 (IV7), Gm7 (iv7), D/F# (I/iii), Bm7 (vi7), Em7 (ii7), E7 (II7), G/A (IV/V)

Chorus:
G7 (IV7), A (V), F#m7 (iii7), B9 (vi9), Em7 (ii7), G/A (IV/V), Dm9 (i9), C (vii), Bb (vib), C (vii), Am7 (v7), D7 (I7), Gm7 (iv7)

Outro interlude:
Bb (vib), C (vii), Am7 (v7), D7 (I7), Gm7 (iv7), A7 (V7) - followed by the verse progression

One take on the keys and three takes on the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Kansas City
description:
This song was originally written by Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller, then Little Richard did his own version, followed by Larry Williams, then the Beatles doing their version and that is the cover that I am doing.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major.

This is a standard blues track and the only thing slightly different is the intro

Intro:
G (I), C (IV), G (I)

Interlude:
C (IV), C# (IV#), D (V)

Verse:
G (I), C (IV), G (I)

Chorus:
D (V), C (IV), G (I)

I used the Fishman Triple Play via the Orange Tree Sample Strawberry vst for the guitar lead

One take on the guitar, two takes on the lead vocals and one take on each of the background vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Kashmir
description:
This song is a Led Zeppelin cover and I love everything about this song. Normally, I love a song if it has a lead guitar, but this is perfect the way that it is.

This was also the first time that my Dad complimented me on how great the song sounded when he heard me practicing the vocals.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of D major.

With that said, it is a special tuning that the Low and High E strings are tuned down by two whole steps, as well as the B string

It is for the aforementioned reason, that I do not play this song on my guitar. I can barely tune a regular tuning with the help of a tuner.

Four takes on the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: La Grange
description:
This song is a ZZ Top cover, that I first heard in the mid 70s and, once more, thanks to John Price who taught me all those songs way back when.

BTW, if I ever have a chance to meet Frank Beard (technically for the second time), then I will ask if he ever worked for Lawson (Bud) Smith, whom I also worked for but in a different decade :-)

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major and there no other chords.

With the exception of the blues interlude/turn around and you can read the midi notes for that.

The synchronization of the animation and video was very difficult. I had to re-render, I don't know how many times.

Anyways, still a little off, but good enough. Even rendering mistakes are recorded.

Two takes on the guitar and one take on the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: La villa strangiato
description:

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major

I: "Buenos Nochas, Mein Froinds!" - (0:00)

VIII: "The Waltz of the Shreves" - (7:26)

Six takes on the acoustic guitar track (kept trying to make it perfect, but oh well), one track on distortion guitar (plenty of mistakes)

title: Levee breaks
description:
This song is a Led Zeppelin cover, that is actually titled "When the Levee breaks" and, for breveties sake, I call it levee breaks

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of F major

Since I am not good at tuning a guitar, I do not play this song because it has a unique tuning with the D string tuned to C, the G string tuned to F, the B string tuned to A and the high E string tuned to C

You can download the midi file listed below for the notes. Very few chords and, with the tuning, I would not know how to extrapolate the music theory correctly

With that said, I only programmed the instruments, with no physical performance, except for the vocals

Three takes with the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Liars World
description:
This song is an original of mine and I wrote it just before 94, which was right before my divorce. We would start to date six months after the divorce, then, after another three months, we would live together off and on for the next five years.

You guessed it, this song is about thinking that someone is totally backing you. When all they are waiting for, is for you to quit on your dream and join theirs. And, yes, this is about thinking that someone believed in my music and finding out that they could give a sh*

I play this in the key of E major.

Verse:
E (I), C (vib), F# (ii), A (IV)

Bridge:
E (I), C (vib), D (viib), E (I)

Chorus:
E (I) to A (IV) - repeat 3 times and finish with C (vib), D (viib), E (I)

Outro:
C (vib), D (viib), E (I) - repeat 4 times

Yes, these are my lyrics and I still messed up.

Two takes on lead vocals and every other track was one take

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Limelight
description:
This song is a Rush cover that I heard when the album "Moving Pictures" came out and, while I love the entire album, I could tell that my favorite band was changing.

I kind of knew that it would happen by the lyrics in their previous album, "glittering prizes and endless compromises will shatter the illusion of integrity," but I still held out hope

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major

Intro:
B (V), B (V), A (IV)

Interlude:
B (V), A (IV), A (IV), E (I)

Verse:
B (V), G# (iii), F# (ii), E (I)

Bridge & Chorus:
E (I), F# (ii), G# (iii)

Four takes on the vocals and two takes on the guitar 

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Little Dreamer
description:
This song is a Van Halen cover from their debut album, back in 78. As you probably know by now, that I fell in love with this album and this band.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of Eb major.

Intro:
C (vi), G (iii)

Verse 1:
C (vi), G (iii), Bb (V), F (ii) - repeat

Interlude/Bridge:
C (vi), G (iii), F (ii)

Verse 2 & 3:
C (vi), G (iii), Bb (V), F (ii)
Ab (IV), Eb (I), Bb (V), G (iii)

The lead is played over the bridge progression and ending with the intro progression.

Three takes for the vocals and background vocals, but one take for the guitar track

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Little Wing
description:
This song is a Hendrix cover and, believe it or not, I heard this song sometime in the early 80s. I had heard other Hendrix songs on the radio, such as, Purple Haze, Foxey Lady, etc..., but it wasn't until Lee Bolden (I think that was his name) let me hear songs that they didn't play on the radio and that is when I fell in love with Hendrix - better late than never

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major.

Intro, Verse & Solo:
Em (vi), G (I), Am (ii), Em (vi), Bm (iii), Bb (iiib), Am (ii), C (IV), G (I), Fadd9 (vii add9), Fsus2 (vii sus2), C (IV), D (V)

One take on the guitar track and two takes on the vocals

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Little bit of sympathy
description:
This song is a Robin Trower cover and, even though this song was released in 74, I first heard this in the early 80s via my friend Marc Sisken, which I wish I knew where he was, because I miss him

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of G major.

No chords and all the notes are in E minor pentatonic, while he flows in and out of minor to major, just like Hendrix used to do.

My sister actually met him in Houston, before he played in the Summit back in the mid 80s

Two takes on the guitar track and one on the vocals - btw, does anyone like or dislike how I double the vocal tracks and slightly offset one to give a natural reverb feel?

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Live wire
description: A very dirty guitar track recorded and this is not a PG song "Live wire" (don't listen if you are under aged) - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Live-wire.mp3

title: Living out to Midnight
description:
This song is a Judas Priest cover and I first heard this song in 1980. I had fallen in love with Priest after I heard the Green Manalishi from the Unleashed in the East a few years before this one.

I do not have the sheet music for this song, but if I had to guess, then I would say it is played in the key of E major

Intro & chorus:
E (I), D (vii), A (IV), B (V) - that's Beethoven

Verse:
E (I), G (iiib) - repeat and end with G (iiib), F# (ii), B (V) - I add D (vii)

Bridge:
A (IV) pull off the 7th - E (I), G (iiib) - repeat four times and end with B (V), D (vii)

The lead is played over the chorus progression.

Two takes for both the guitar and vocals

title: Long tall Sally
original_band: Little Richard et all The Beatles
description:
This song was written by Robert "Bumps" Blackwell, Enotris Johnson, and Little Richard; recorded by Little Richard; and released in March 1956. Later, the Beatles would cover this song. I first heard it when I purchased the Beatles' "Rock 'n Roll music" album in the 80s. The double album was issued on June 1976

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major

Verse:
G (I), C (IV), G (I) 

Chorus:
D (V), C (IV), G (I)

One take on the keys' track and seven takes on the vocals' track.

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Looks that kill
description: I love Motley Crue and I learned this song for a co-worker "She's got the looks that kill" - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Looks-that-kill.mp3

title: Louder
description: I learned another Crue song that I love "Louder" - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Louder.mp3

title: Love Bites
description:
This song is a Def Leppard cover and I first heard it back in '87. Believe it or not, I was not a fan until I heard this song, which lead to me giving the band a second chance and found out that I missing out on one of the greatest bands of all time.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of F major. I did not program these notes, but I did make modifications to the original midi file that I download a couple of decades ago. Whomever made that file, you did a great job.

I only recorded the lead section. You should treat yourself and listen to the original. With that said, as usual the midi, tab and words are available for download below.

Verse:
Dm (vi), Gmadd9 (ii add9), C7sus4 (V7 sus4), Fadd9 (I add9)

Bridge - change to Eb major:
Eb (I), Ab (IV), F (ii), Bb (V)

Chorus - still in the key of Eb major:
Cm (vi), Ab (IV), F (ii), Bb (V) - repeat two more times and end on Bbsus2

No guitar pick is used in this song. Three takes on the guitar track, four takes on the lead vocals track and one take on the background vocals track.

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Manic Depression
description:
This song is a Hendrix cover that I would hear on the radio frequently in the 70s. While songs like Purple Haze and Hey Joe were played more frequently than other Hendrix songs, I gravitated to songs like Fire, Foxey Lady and this one.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of C major or A minor, depending on your perspective. I choose to view it as A minor because so much of the A minor pentatonic is used in the song, but as Hendrix always does, he weaves in and out of the major & minor scales so well

There are no actual chords played, but rather a series of notes, that you can view via the midi or tab files

Verse & Bridge:
A (i), G (vii)

Chorus:
E (V), G (vii), D (IV), C (iii), G (vii)

One take on the guitar and vocal tracks

As usual all mistakes are recorded

title: Merry go round
description:
This is a Motley Crue song from their debut album "Too fast for love," that I used to listen to everyday in the early 80s

I do not have the sheet music to this song, so I do not know what key it is played in. I downloaded the midi file for this song somewhere around 2011 and I learned how to play it from that midi file

The original midi file was tuned down a whole step from the traditional tuning

There are four guitar tracks from what I can hear and I only play one of them.

Two takes on the guitar track and three takes on the vocals

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Michelle
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover from their debut album "Appetite for Destruction" and I first heard it in '87, when I went to Los Angeles for the first time.

There was a local channel that played videos and you could call in on two lines to vote. They called the show "Smash or Trash" and "Welcome to the Jungle" was the video that I saw. Many people called in to vote for smash, which lead to MTV picking it up and the rest is 80s rock history.

From there, I purchased the casette tape and fell in love with the entire album. The guitar riffs are based on F# (vi) pentatonic and blues scales. When I would play these songs, it was the first time that my now ex-wife would tell me that I sounded just like Slash, which it was very rare for her to compliment or acknowledge something positive, unless it was absolutely true or undeniable. I wish that would have happened more. Oh well, that's why I sometimes refer to this song as me-hell.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of A major. I decided to take the parts played by guitars in the intro and turned them into orchestral instruments.

Intro:
A/C# (I/iii), Am sus2/C (i/iiib), B7 (ii7), F# (vi)

Verse:
C# (iii), C (iiib), B (ii), A (I), F# (vi), A (I), E (V), F# (vi)
C# (iii), C (iiib), B (ii), D (IV)
C# (iii), C (iiib), B (ii), A (I), F# (vi), A (I), E (V), F# (vi)
C# (iii), C (iiib), B (ii), A (I), F# (vi), A (I), E (V), F# (vi)

Chorus:
D (IV), E (V), B (ii)
C# (iii), E (V), A (I)
D (IV), C# (iii), B (ii), A (I)

Bridge:
E (V), D (IV), A (I), B (ii), G (vii), E (V), B (ii) - believe it or not, that is Beethoven

One take on the guitar, two takes on keys (camera fell on the first take) and one take on vocals

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Money
description:
This is a Pink Floyd cover and I first heard this song in the early 70s. I actually thought they were saying Monem, which is part of my last name. I was somewhere between eight or nine years old.

I do not have any sheet music for this song and this is one of the songs that I did not program. I found the midi file long ago, so long ago that I do not remember if it was the late 90s or early into the new century.

If I had to guess, then I would say it is in the key of B major and the lead is based on the B pentatonic scale

Two takes for the lead guitar and two takes for the vocals

All mistakes were recorded

title: Mother natures son
description:
This is a Beatles cover from their "white" album. I first heard this song after purchasing the double sided album in mid 70s.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of D major

Intro:
Bm (vi), Bm7 (vi7), Bm6 (vi6), E (ii), D (I)

Verse:
D (I), G/D (IV/I), G/D (IV/I), D (I)
Bm (vi), Bm7 (vi7), Bm6 (vi6), Bm7/E (vi7/ii)
A (V), D/A (I/V), A (V), D/A (I/V), A (V), D/A (I/V)
D (I), Dm7 (i7), G/D (IV/I), D (I) - repeat

Lead section:
D (I), Dm7 (i7), G/D (IV/I), D (I) - repeat and end with D (I), Augmented D7 (I7), D7 (I7), G/D (IV/I), Gm/D (iv/I), D (I)

Outro:
D (I), G/D (IV/I), G/D (IV/I), D (I)

Two takes on guitar and five takes on the vocals

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Mr Brownstone
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover from their debut album "Appetite for Destruction" and I first heard it in '87, when I went to Los Angeles for the first time.

There was a local channel that played videos and you could call in on two lines to vote. They called the show "Smash or Trash" and "Welcome to the Jungle" was the video that I saw. Many people called in to vote for smash, which lead to MTV picking it up and the rest is 80s rock history.

From there, I purchased the casette tape and fell in love with the entire album. They use a "Bo Diddley" beat during the intro and Slash uses E Dorian (E, F#, G, A, B, C#, D) with G#, E pentatonic minor (E, G, A, B, D), F# pentatonic minor (F#, A, B, C#, E), G pentatonic minor (G, Bb, C, D, F), C pentatonic minor (C, Eb, F, G, Bb) and D pentatonic minor (D, F, G, A, C)

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of G major

Intro:
E (vi), D (V), E (vi), D (V), A (ii), B (iii), G (I)

Verse:
E (vi), A (ii) - repeat

Chorus:
G (I), F (viib), G (I), C (IV), Bb (iiib), C (IV), D (V), C (IV), D (V) end on E (vi)

Bridge:
B (iii), A (ii), B (iii), A (ii), G (I), A (ii) - repeat

The lead is played over the bridge progression and ending using the aforementioned pentatonic scales played over the chorus progression

Five takes on the guitar (couldn't switch in and out of effects for the various sections) and one take for the vocals

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Mr Crowley
description:
This is an Ozzy Osbourne cover from the time he had Randy Rhoads as his guitarist. I had a chance to go see Ozzy & Randy but I thought I would catch them on their next tour. Unfortunately for me, Randy passed away and, from that point, I never missed going to a show of an artist that I wanted to see perform live.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of F major. There are four guitar tracks and I only played one of the tracks.

Verse:
Dm (vi), Bb (IV) - repeat
C (V), F (I), Dm (vi), C (V), Bb (IV), A (iii)

First lead played over the verse

Interlude:
Dm (vi), Bb (IV), C (V), Dm (vi), Bb (IV), Em7 (viib7), A (iii)

Second lead:
Dm (vi), Gm7 (ii7), C (V), F (I), Bb (IV), Em7 (viib7) - repeat and end with Asus4 (iii sus4), A (iii)

The beginning of the second lead has two guitar tracks for the lead and one is slower than the other, I played the slower part, followed by going it alone through the rest of the solo.

One take on the guitar track and nine takes on the vocals (had to restart Cubase to purge the memory of the VSTs)

All mistakes were recorded.

title: My Life
description:
This is a Billy Joel cover from his '78 album "52nd Street" and first heard it as the theme song to a tv series called "Bosom Buddies," which introduced a young Tom Hanks in his debut role.

I would watch the show with my Mom (RIP) and she told me that she saw me growing up to be like Tom Hanks. Of course, at this time this role of Tom Hanks was to dress up like a woman, so that he could live in building that only allowed women. I said to my Mom, "great, you see the future me as someone who has to dress as a woman, just to have a place to live?" And she replied, "laa, hwa lazeeze," which translates to "no, he's cute"

As a result of watching this show with her, she would hear the theme song to the show and say that this was my anthem. Since I cannot play this song very well, with both hands, I only play it in homage of my Mom.

This song has two keyboard tracks and I try to combine the two into one, which translates to leaving the left out of the equation from time to time.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of D major.

Intro:
D (I)

Interlude:
G/D (IV/I), D (I), C9 (vii), Eb7/F (iib7/iii), F7 (iii7), Bb (vib) - end with a descending chromatic Bb, A, Ab

Verse:
D (I), D/F# (I/iii), G (IV), A7 (V7), A (V), D (I) - I only play A not A7

Bridge:
Bm (vi), F#7/C# (iii7/VII), D9 (I9), E9 (ii9), G (IV), D/F# (I/iii), F#7 (iii7)
Bm (vi), Bm7/E (vi7/ii), E7 (ii7), G/A (IV/V), A (V), G/A (IV/V), A (V)

One take on the vocals and one take on keys, with plenty of mistakes

All mistakes were recorded.

title: My Sweet Lord
description:
This is a George Harrison cover from his debut solo triple sided album "All things must pass" in 1970. This is one of the few songs, after the Beatles break, where John Lennon, Ringo Starr and George Harrison record together, along with Badfinger (backing vocals) and the musicians who backed the Temptations on various instruments.

I do not have the sheet music to this song, but if I had to guess, then I would say that it starts in the key of F# major and changes to the key of Ab major

Verse 1 & 2:
F# (I), B (IV) - repeat four times
E (viib), C# (V) - repeat two times

Chorus 1 & 2:
E (viib), Faug (vii), Fdim (vii)

Interlude:
E9

After changing to Ab
Verse 3 & 4:
Ab (I), Db (IV) - repeat four times
F (viib), Eb/Bb (IV/V) - repeat two times - I play Gb instead of F

Chorus 3 & 4:
F (vii), Gbaug (vii), Gbdim (vii) - I play Gb instead of F

One take on the lead and background vocals, one take on the acoustic guitar and two takes on the lead

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Natural Science
description:
This is a Rush cover from their Permanent Waves album and I heard it when it came out. While other songs from the album, such as Spirit of the Radio, Freewill, etc..., are more famous, this song is not only my favorite on the album, but my favorite Rush song ever.

I have an anthology Rush book, which means that some of the things that I do may not be according to the original sheet music, but according to the anthology, this song is played in the key of D major to E major in the intro, followed by changing to G major, then changing to A major 

With that said, I have no music theory section for this song, but you can see the chords and notes that I play with the tabs. I play the notes in the first four verses a whole step up to match the midi file that I downloaded so long ago.

Ten takes for the guitar track (one technical issue after another) and one take for the vocals. I had to restart Cubase several times to make the animations of the instruments

All mistakes were recorded.

title: New World Man
description:
This is a Rush cover from their Signals album and this song completely described me at the time.

According to the song book that I have, this is in the key of D major

Intro & verse:
D (I), F (iii)

Bridge:
F (iii), Bbsus2 (vib sus2), Gm (iv)

Chorus:
D (I), F (iii), Bbsus2 (vib sus2), Gm (iv) 

Four takes on the guitar track (several technical issues switching to distorted and back to clean) and three takes on vocals

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Night Train
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover from their debut album "Appetite for Destruction" and I first heard it in '87, when I went to Los Angeles for the first time.

There was a local channel that played videos and you could call in on two lines to vote. They called the show "Smash or Trash" and "Welcome to the Jungle" was the video that I saw. Many people called in to vote for smash, which lead to MTV picking it up and the rest is 80s rock history.

From there, I purchased the casette tape and fell in love with the entire album. Single note triads in A Dorian (A, B, C, D, E, F#, G), then G major (G,A,B,C,D,E,F#), followed by A Pentatonic major (A,C,D,E,G) and finally D pentatonic major (D,E,F#,A,B)

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of C major and, in the first two leads, it changes to the key of A major and returns to C major for the last lead

Intro & Interlude/Bridge:
A (vi), A7 (vi7), D/A (ii/vi), C/A (iii/vi), G (V), F (IV), G (V), Gsus4 (V sus4), A (vi), G (V), A (vi)

Verse:
A (vi)

Chorus:
A (vi), F (IV), G (V)

Three takes on the guitar track and two takes on the vocals

All mistakes were recorded.

title: No one like you
description:
This is a Scorpions cover from their "Blackout" album in 1982 and, while I heard it on the radio when it came out, I had no idea who the Scorpions were until I got into them in '87, when I was in Los Angeles and I fell in love with them. Believe it or not, an Egyptian guy living in Torance, turned me on to them, when he let me hear his favorite songs

I do not have the sheet music, but if I had to guess, then I would say that this song is played in the key of C major. There are four guitar tracks and I try to combine all of them. I turn down the volume of my guitar track during the verse because it is too distorted. Also, this song really kicked my computers ass with the four guitar tracks and, as a result, I had to do a lot of video editing to match the drums - still did not match up, but until I have a more powerful computer, other than a mac mini, this is the best that I could do with what I have.

Intro & Chorus:
A (vi), F (IV), G (V)

Verse:
Am (vi), F (IV) - repeat three times and end on C (I)

One take for the guitar track and one take on vocals 

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Nobody home
description:
This is a Pink Floyd cover from their album "The Wall" and I heard this album the day that it was released. While I listened to it, I was measuring it up against "Dark side of the moon" and "Wish you were here," which is unfair and, after I listened a few times, I began to love this album as much as the two aforementioned albums.

This song happens to be one of my favorites in all of the Pink Floyd songs and, according to the sheet music, this song is played in the key of C major.

Intro:
Am (vi), C+ (I), C (I), D7 (ii7), F (IV), Fm (iv)

Verse:
C (I), E (iii), F (IV), C (I), F (IV), C (I)

Bridge:
C (I), C7 (I7), F (IV), Fm (iv), C (I), E7 (iii7), Am (vi), D7 (ii7), G (V), E7 (iii7)

Chorus:


Am (vi), C (I), D (ii), Fm6 (iv6)

Interlude:
C (I), F (IV), C (I)

One take on keys track and three takes on vocals - I believe it is one of my best to date

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Nobodys fault but mine
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover from the "Presence" album and I heard it when it came out in 1976. While the understanding of the lyrics became much more deeper for me as time went along, I found it calling me again when I moved to sobriety in the early 90s.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major

Intro & Interlude:
E (I)

Verse:
D (viib), E (I) - repeat four times and end with G (iii), A (IV)

Second Interlude:
E (I), A (IV)

Harmonica & guitar leads:
E (I), A (IV) - repeat followed by playing the verse progression

Three takes on the guitar track and two takes on the vocals track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Nothing else matters
description:
This is a Metallica cover and I first heard this song in the early 90s. There were a lot of people that were huge fans in the 80s, which did not like the new sound, but I thought it showed a lot of growth & development of their art and this song is an excellent example of that fruition. 

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major or E minor, depending on your perspective and I choose to see it as E minor.

Intro, first lead & Outro:
Em (i), Am (IV), C (vi), D (vii), Em (i)

Verse:
Em (i), D (vii), Dsus4 (vii sus4), Cadd2 (vi add2)

Chorus:
C (vi), D (vii), Dsus4 (vii sus4), Dadd2 (vii add2), D (vii)

Second lead:
E (i), B (V), E (i), D (vii), C (vi), G (iii), F# (ii)

Plenty of mistakes in the beginning, but not bad for two takes on the guitar track and five takes on the vocals track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Ocean
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover and I heard this on the radio in the early 70s. While I liked the songs Led Zeppelin was coming out with, I didn't become a huge fan until I saw the movie "The song remains the same," which features several mistakes/improv moments and I loved it. Maybe it's why I am driven towards recording all my mistakes, because it is a what you see is what you get way of operating

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major

Intro & interlude:
series of notes played in A (I) - see midi or tabs for notes

Verse:
D (IV), C (iiib), A (I), G (viib), A (I), C (iiib), D (IV)

The interlude in the second or outro solo:
A (I), D (IV), E (V) - played over a blues bass progression. Also, classic Beethoven

Four takes for the guitar track and three takes for the vocals track.

title: Octopuses Garden
description:
This is a Beatles cover and, while I had heard the song before, I first knew it was the Beatles in the early 70s, when my uncle purchased the 67-70 double album.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major.

Intro:
E (I)

Verse:
E (I), C#m (vi), A (IV), B (V) - repeat - classic pop progression, which is borrowed from Beethoven

Chorus:
C#m (vi), B (V), A (IV)

Lead:
E (I), A (IV), F#m (ii), D (viib) - repeat and end with E (I), A (IV), B (V)

One take for the guitar track and two takes for the vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Old Brown Shoe
description:
This is a Beatles cover and, while I had heard the song before, I first knew it was the Beatles in the early 70s, when my uncle purchased the 67-70 double album.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of C major

Intro and Outro:
C7 (I7)

Verse:
C7 (I7), Dm7 (ii7), F (IV), F7 (IV7), Ab (vib), Ab7 (vib7)

Chorus:
F (IV), E+ (iii augmented), Am (vi)

Bridge:
G (V), F (IV) - repeat
F#0 (IV# diminished), G (V)

The lead is played over the verse progression. I finish the outro by adding the chorus progression

One take for the guitar and key's track. Two takes on the vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Out of love
description:
This is a Van Halen cover from their second album "Van Halen II" and I first heard this song in the late 70s, when it came out.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major or E minor. I choose to dissect this song using E minor.

Intro:
C# (vi)

Verse:
Series of notes played of E - E (i), D (vii), E (i), G (iii), E (i), D (vii), E (i), G (iii - octave lower), E (i), D (vii), E (i), G (iii)
End with chords - E (i), D (vii), E (i) 

Bridge:
B (V), C (vib), C# (vi), C (vib), C# (vi), D (vii), C# (vi), D (vii), D# (vii#), D (vii), D# (vii#), E (i), Bb (Vb), A (IV)

Chorus: 
C (vi) - this is supposed to be E but I play a C, Bb (Vb), A (IV), notes roll C, Bb, E - repeat four times

Both leads are played over E - the first lead is litterally a repeat of the verse progression, but the second is a rolling bass and fluid drums played over E minor

Two takes for the guitar and vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Out 2 get me
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover from their debut album "Appetite for Destruction" and I first heard it in '87, when I went to Los Angeles for the first time.

There was a local channel that played videos and you could call in on two lines to vote. They called the show "Smash or Trash" and "Welcome to the Jungle" was the video that I saw. Many people called in to vote for smash, which lead to MTV picking it up and the rest is 80s rock history.

From there, I purchased the casette tape and fell in love with the entire album. G minor tonality with the lead using G Dorian mode (G, A, Bb, C, D, E, F)

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of Bb major

Intro, Verse, Chorus & outro:
G (vi), Bb (I), G (vi), F (V), G (vi), C (ii), Bb (I), G (vi), Bb (I), G (vi)

Bridge:
D (iii), C (ii), Bm (iib), Am (vii)

Interlude:
C (ii), Bb (I)

One take on both guitar and vocal's tracks.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Over the mountain
description:
This is an Ozzy Osbourne cover with Randy Rhodes on guitar. While this song came out in the early 80s, I did not hear it until '88

I do not have the sheet music for this song and, therefore, I have no music theory for this one.

You can download the tab/midi for the chords and notes. There are three guitar tracks and I try to combine them.

One take on both guitar and six takes on the vocal's tracks (more difficult than it sounds).

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Paradise City
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover from their debut album "Appetite for Destruction" and I first heard it in '87, when I went to Los Angeles for the first time.

There was a local channel that played videos and you could call in on two lines to vote. They called the show "Smash or Trash" and "Welcome to the Jungle" was the video that I saw. Many people called in to vote for smash, which lead to MTV picking it up and the rest is 80s rock history.

From there, I purchased the casette tape and fell in love with the entire album. G pentatonic major and minor scales are used

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of G major

Intro, verse & outro lead:
G (I), C (IV), F (viib), C (IV), G (I) - if they would have played F#, then this would have been right out of Beethoven's playbook.

First lead:
G (I), C (IV), Bb (iiib) - repeat three times and change to A (ii), C (IV), A (ii), D (V), C (IV), G (I), Bb (iiib), G (I), F (viib), C (IV)

Interlude:
D (V), C (IV) - repeat twice and end with C (IV), Bb (iiib)

One take on the guitar and the vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Paranoid
description:
This is an Ozzy Randy Rhodes/Black Sabbath cover, that I first heard in the early 70s and I got into Sabbath in '76.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E minor

Intro:
Em (i)

Verse:
Em (i), D (ii), G (iii), D (ii) - repeat

Bridge:
Em (i), D (ii)

The lead is played over the verse progression

Four takes for the guitar track and two takes for the vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Piece of your action
description: Song number 232 "Piece of your action" - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Piece-of-your-action.mp3. Once again, all the Motley Crue songs were not part of the original list. I learned and recorded this songs because a huge fan, from across the hall where I still have a day job, requested that I record these songs. I believe he was testing me. Hope, I passed.

title: Piggies
description:
This is a Beatles cover from their "White" album and I first heard this song in the mid 70s. This is one of my favorite George Harrison songs, which mocks how the upper class is causing many problems with the rest of society.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of Ab major

Intro:
Ab (I), Eb (V) - repeat

Verse:
Ab (I), Eb (V) - play three times
Fm (vi), Bb7 (ii7) - repeat
E (vib), F (vi), F# (vi#), G (vii)

Bridge:
Ab (I), Eb (V), C (iii)

Chorus:
Bbm (ii), C (iii), Db (IV), Ab/Eb (I/V)
Bbm (ii), C (iii), Db (IV), Eb (V)

Harpsichord lead is played over the verse progression

One take on the guitar track and two takes on the vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Please please me she loves u i feel fine
description:
These are three Beatles cover from their early years and I first these songs in the early 70s, when I purchased their 1962-1966 double album.

According the sheet music that I have:
Please please me is played in the key of E major
She loves you is played in the key of E minor - sung in German, my first attempt at singing in German
I feel fine is played in the key of G major

Please please me:
Intro:
E (I)

Verse:
E (I), A (IV), E (I), G (iii), A (IV), B (V), E (I), A (IV), E (I)

Chorus:
A (IV), F# (ii), C#m (vi), A (IV)

Bridge:
A (IV), B (V), E (I), A (IV), B (V) - classic Beethoven

Outro:
E (I), G (iii), C (vib), B (V), E (I)

She loves you:
Intro:
Em (i), A7 (IV7), C (vib), G (iii)

Verse:
G (iii), Em (i), Bm (v), D (vii)

Chorus:
G (iii), Em (i), Cm (vib), D7 (vii)

I feel fine:
Intro:
D (V), C (IV), G (I)

Verse:
G (I), D (V), C (IV)

Chorus:
G (I), Bm (iii), C (IV), D7 (V7)
G (I), Bm (iii), Am (ii), D7 (V7)

The lead is played over the verse progression

Two takes on the guitar track and 

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Polk Salad Annie
description:
This is my favorite Elvis song and I do not hold a candle to James Burton, but I love this song 

This is an Elvis cover and I first heard this song, after my Uncle purchased the "Elvis: Live in Madison Garden" in 1973. I loved this entire album and, if you want to hear the best live recording ever, then treat yourself to this one

I do not have any sheet music for this song and therefore there is no music theory analysis. 

Three takes on the guitar track and four takes on the vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Powerslave
description:
This is my favorite Iron Maiden song and I first heard it in the mid 80s.

I have no sheet music for this song and, therefore, there is no music theory breakdown of the song

There are three guitar tracks and I try to combine two of them. I mute out the interlude section of the lead, because I messed up big time, but at the same time, I knew that I did not want to start over for a second take.

One take on the guitar and vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Purple Haze
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover and I first heard this song in the early 70s. While I was just a little kid, I did not understand the song and I would not like it that much until I heard the live version from the Woodstock album. A girl named Martha Goldberg, who lived a couple of blocks away, had the recording and I fell in love with Hendrix in concert. This would be followed by meeting a guy named Lee Bolden (I think that's right, I am bad with names) turned me on to several bootleg albums, after I told him of my encounter with listening to the Woodstock version.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of E minor

Intro, Interlude and lead are played over E

Verse:
E9 (i9), G (iii), A (IV) - I play A (IV), B (V) - Beethoven would have

Several technical issues - four takes on the guitar track and three takes on the vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Red Barchetta
description:
This is a Rush cover from their "Moving Pictures" album and I first heard it when it came out in February 1981. It was a few months after the passing of John Lennon and I really needed something good in my life. The Universe gave me this album to listen to and inspire me to go towards this kind of music - it was a life saver, as far as I am concerned.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of D major and changes to C major

I combine three guitar tracks into one

Intro & Verse:
Asus4 (V sus4), Asus4/F# (V sus4/iii), Asus4/G (V sus4/IV), Dsus2 (I sus2)

Change to C major:
F (IV), G (V)

Change back to D major:
G (vi), A (V), D (I), G (vi), A (V), Asus4 (V sus4)

Change to C major - Down at his farm
Interlude:
F (IV),	C (I), F (IV), G (V) - Beethoven

D major - Wind in my hair:
G/D (vi/I),	A/D (V/I)

Well-weathered leather
Bb (vib), F (iiib),	C# (VII), G# (IV#) - repeat 
E (ii),	B (vi), G (vi), D (I)

Lead is played over D major

One take on the guitar track and two takes on the vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Red House
description:
This is a Jimi Hendrix cover from his debut album "Are You Experienced" and Noel Redding is playing a guitar for the bass track. I have always loved the blues and this has to be one of my all time favorites, along side Eric Claptons "Further on down the road"

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of B major

Intro:
B7 (I7), B- (I-), B (I)
E7 (IV7), B7 (I7), F#7 (V7), E7 (IV7), B7 (I7), E7 F7 F#7 (IV7 V7b V7) - this progression is used for the rest of the song

One take on the guitar and vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Reminder
description:
This is one of my originals from way back and I have had many a bass player quit after practicing the song a few times.

Played in the key of E minor

Intro:
An old vamp progression from the late 50s - played over E

Em (i), A (IV), Em (i), B (V), A (IV), Em (i) - look familiar, that's right it's Beethoven, except I play an E minor instead of E major

Outro:
Em (i), D (viib), C# (vi), B (V), Em (i)
E (i) E (i) F# (ii) - repeat three times, one octave higher each time, followed by raising G to A, and ending with A to E - if that sounds familiar, then that is because it is a simplistic rendition of Rachmaninoff

Six takes on the guitar (yeah, it's my own song, but I had one technical issue after another, including the lead - did you notice how weak it sounded, but I had to keep going) and one take on the vocal's track

As you may have guessed by now, I stopped using my cry baby wah pedal because of all the technical issues and began using the MXR-90, which creates a comprable sound, but has unexpected outcomes

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Revolution
description:
This is a Beatles cover and I first heard the song in the early 70s after my uncle bought the 1967-1970 double album

According to the sheet music that I have, this is in the key of Bb major

Intro:
Bb (I)

Verse:
Bb (I), Eb (IV) - repeat and end with F7 (V7)

Bridge:
G/C#m (vi/iiib), F7 (V), C#m (iiib), Ab (viib), Bb (I), G (vi), F (V)

Chorus:
Bb (I), Eb (IV), G (vi), Eb (IV)

Two takes on the guitar track, one take on the vocal's and key's track - Obviously I cannot play the piano as George Martin, but I have tried

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Rock n Roll
description:
This is a Led Zeppelin cover from their forth album and this was on the radio all the time in the early 70s. While I enjoyed this band, I fell in love with them after hearing their live album "The song remains the same," which shows a raw and powerful version of their studio genius intertwining with the energy that their fans return to them.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of A major.

Intro, interlude, lead, outro and verse:
A (I) repeat, D (IV), A (I), E (V), D (IV) - does that look familiar, it is because this is classic Beethoven, while being played with a blues beat

Three takes on the vocal's track, one take on the guitar and key's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Rock of ages
description:
This is a Def Leppard cover that I heard in the early 80s and, while I do not hold a candle to Joe Elliot's voice, I believe that I do the lead guitar, drums and bass justice in this recording.

I do not have the sheet music, which equals no music theory.

Two takes on the guitar and the vocal's track. Six takes for the back up vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Rock you like a hurricane
description:
This is a Scorpions cover from their "Love at First Sting" album in 1984 and, while I heard it on the radio when it came out, I had no idea who the Scorpions were until I got into them in '87, when I was in Los Angeles and I fell in love with them. Believe it or not, an Egyptian guy living in Torance, turned me on to them, when he let me hear his favorite songs

I do not have the sheet music, but if I had to guess, then I would say that this song is played in the key of C major. There are four guitar tracks and I try to combine all of them. 

Intro & Chorus:
E (iii), G (V), A (vi), C (I), D (ii)

Verse:
C (I), E (iii), C (I), E (iii), D (ii)

Six takes for the guitar track (I originally recorded with my SCORPION 32 preset on the RP500, but lead section did not sound as good as when I used the CRAZYTRA 14 preset) and five takes for the vocal's track (very difficult)

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Rocket Queen
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover and I was in LA when this album came out, specifically the hit single "Welcome to Jungle" on a local TV show called "Smash or Trash," which aired the video. A viewer could call in to vote on whether it was smash or trash. I called in on the line that it was a smash.

GnR would later put out the album "Appetite for Destruction" which I fell in love with and I still say that the drumming is what made these songs special. They fit perfect with Slash's guitar, Axel's voice and lyrics.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of A major, then E major.

Six takes for the guitar track (although, GoPro says it's only five takes), five takes for the vocal's track and one take on the keys.

Intro:
E/F#m (V/vi)

Verse:
F# (vi), B/A (ii/I), E (V)
F# (vi), B (ii), C# (iii), E (V)

Chorus:
B A (ii I), F# (vi), F# G# (vi vii), E (V), A (I) repeat, B (ii), E (V)

Switch to E major
Verse:
E (I), B (V), C# (vi), E (I), A (IV), B (V) - repeat

End with 
E (I), B (V), C# (vi), E (I), D# (vii), C# (vi), B (V), A (IV), G# (iii), E (I)

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Rocketman
description:
This is an Elton John cover and I heard this song in early 70s. Back then, Elton was in the top 40 charts all the time and he was my first favorite artist before I was familiar with Elvis and the Beatles - I heard their songs but I had no idea who they were, until my uncle purchased the Live at Madison Square Garden by Elvis and the 1967-1970 album by the Beatles in '73.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of Bb major

Verse:
Gm (vi), C (ii)

Bridge:
Bb/D (I/iii), Eb (IV), Bb/D (I/iii), Cm (ii), Cm/Bb (ii/I), F/A (V/vii)

Chorus:
Bb (I), Eb/Bb (IV/I), Bb (I), Eb/Bb (IV/I), Bb/D (I/iii), C (ii), Eb (IV), Bb (I)

One take on the keyboard and vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Roll over Beehtoven
description:
This is a 1956 hit single by Chuck Berry, originally released on Chess Records, with "Drifting Heart" as the B-side. I first heard the Beatles version when I purchased the "Rock n Roll music" double album in the mid 80s.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of D major.

Intro, verse and bridge:
D (I), G (IV), D (I), G (IV), D (I), A (V), G (IV) - standard twelve bar blues, but it is really Beethoven, hence the title

From tonic to sub-dominant to tonic to sub-dominant to tonic to dominant to sub-dominant to tonic - classic Beethoven

I play a Stevie Ray Vaughn like version

Two takes on the guitar and vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Run like hell
description:
This is a Pink Floyd cover and I first heard this when the Wall came out in the late 70s.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the D major. This song has four guitar tracks and I try to combine them into one.

Intro:
D (I) A/D (V/I), G/D (IV/I) D (I), A/D (V/I) G/D (IV/I), A (V) D (I)

Interlude:
D (I), F (iiib), A (V), D (I)

Verse:
E (ii), F (iiib), E (ii), C (viib), B (vi), Em (ii), D (I)

The lead is played over the verse progression. 

One take on the guitar and backup vocal's track, two takes on the lead vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: SATO
description:
This is an Ozzy Osbourne with Randy Rhoads cover and I first heard this song in the mid 80s.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in E minor

Intro:
Em (i), C (vib), A (IV), D (vii)

Verse:
Em (i), C (vib), A (IV), B (V), A G E (IV iii V)

Lead is played over E minor and switches to G

Two takes on the guitar track and one the vocal's track

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Savoy Truffle
description:
This is a Beatles cover that George Harrison wrote about his best friend's (Eric Clapton) sweet tooth. I first heard this song after purchasing the "White" album in the late 70s and it continues to be one of my favorite Beatle's songs.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E minor

Verse:
Em (i), F# (ii), G (iii), B (V)

Chorus:
Em (i), C/E (vib/i), Em6 (i6), C (vib)

Bridge:
Em (i), A (IV), Asus4 (IV sus4), A (IV), G (iii), B (V)

Five takes on the guitar track, two takes on lead vocal's track and one take on background vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Saw her standing there
description:
This is a Beatles cover their early years and I first found out that it was by the Beatles, when I purchased the "Rock n Roll music" album in the mid 80s

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E major

Intro & interlude:
E7 (I)

Verse:
E7 (I7), A7 (IV7), E7 (I7)

Chorus:
E7 (I7), A7 (IV7), C (vib), E7 (I7), B7 (V7), E7 (I7)

Bridge:
A7 (IV7), B7 (V7), E7 (I7)

The lead is played over the verse and chorus progressions

One take on the guitar track, two takes on lead and background vocal's tracks each.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Scooby Dooby Do
original_band: Ben Raleigh with help from Hoyt Curtin
description: Song number 234 is special to me. I learned how to play this song for my niece Shawna A Monem "Scooby Dooby Do" - http://kronusproductions.com/uploads/playMp3.php?mPlaySong=Scooby-Dooby-Do.mp3

title: Sgt Peppers With a little help Reprise
description:
These are Beatles covers from their "Sergent Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" album and I first heard this song in the early 70s. I found out it was the Beatles when my uncle purchased the 1967-1970 double album.

According to the sheet music that I have:

Sgt. Peppers is played in the key of G major

Intro:
A (ii) - repeat, C (IV)

Verse:
G7 (I7), A7 (ii7), C7 (IV7) - repeat two more times
G7 (I7), C7 (IV7), G7 (I7)

Verse 2:
G (I), Bb (iiib), C7 (IV7), G (I), C7 (IV7), G7 (I7)

Bridge:
C7 (IV7), F7 (viib), C7 (IV7), D7 (V7)

Verse 3:
G7 (I7), A7 (ii7), C7 (IV7) - repeat two more times
G7 (I7), C7 (IV7), G7 (I7)

title: Someone saved my life tonight
description:
This is an Elton John cover and, as you probably know by now, he was my first music idol. In the mid 70s, this song was on the radio all the time.

Ironically, I was learning how to play this song in '94. When I was working out the part in the chorus "and Butterflies are free to fly, fly away, high away" - that is when I received the news that Mike Bracken passed away. I have had seven best friends in my life and Mike was one of the seven

Ever since, it has been difficult to play this song and you would think that enough time has passed, but it hasn't and this song will always have a special place in my heart as a result

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of Ab major

title: Star Trek TOS theme
description:
This is an instrumental musical piece composed by Alexander Courage for Star Trek, the science fiction television series created by Gene Roddenberry and originally aired between September 8, 1966, and June 3, 1969

When my family and I came to Houston in 1969, I only knew three words in English. I would mimic the other kids in the apartment complex and they soon grew tired of that, to the point, which they would run away when they would see me coming. Also, in 1969 Star Trek TOS (the original series) had begun running in syndication (repeating on air through network affiliates), which they showed every day and, by mimicking what I heard, that is how I learned how to speak English. Thanks to William Shatner, I had gigantic pauses between my sentences until I reached Jr. High

No sheet music equals no music theory

title: Sweet Child
description:
This is a Guns n Roses cover and I was in LA when this album came out, specifically the hit single "Welcome to Jungle" on a local TV show called "Smash or Trash," which aired the video. A viewer could call in to vote on whether it was smash or trash. I called in on the line that it was a smash.

GnR would later put out the album "Appetite for Destruction" which I fell in love with and I still say that the drumming is what made these songs special. They fit perfect with Slash's guitar, Axel's voice and lyrics.

According to the sheet music that I have, this is played in the key of D major. The use of the D major scale (D, E, F#, G, A, B, C#). During the lead played E minor tonal E Aeolian (E, F#, G, A, B, C, D) to E harmonic minor (E, F#, G, A, B, C, D#) - end solo E pentatonic minor (E, G, A, B, C, D)

title: To the one
description:
This is a KRONUS Productions original, that I wrote, along with handfull of other songs, back in 1976 shortly after my first best friend, Dilbert Jones, passed away. I often credit Dilbert with these songs, because they seemed to come out of nowhere, once again, after his passing.

I was twelve years old at the time, and with that said, the music theory was not taken into account. As a result, there are some things that do not make sense, because it was based on what sounds good to me, as opposed to what is musically correct.

Let's say it is in the key of E minor

Intro:
G (iii), F (iib), D (vii), Am (IV), Em (i) - looking back, I should have used F# instead of F, but it is probably because I had an aversion to playing sharps or flats. Had the black keys been the same height, then at twelve years old, I might not have tried to avoid them

Verse:
G (iii), B (V)

I tried to explain how this song would be with all the instruments that I had in mind, but even my closest friends and family could not see it. Especially, since I was playing everything on an acoustic guitar, with the explanation of, "And the strings would do this... and the drums would do this here..." 

One take on the guitar and vocal's track.

All mistakes were recorded.

title: Welcome to the jungle
description:
This is a Guns 'N Roses cover, "Welcome to the Jungle," and I was in LA when this album came out, specifically the video for this song was on a local TV show called "Smash or Trash," which aired the video. Viewers could call in to vote on whether it was smash or trash. I called in on the line that it was a smash.

GnR would later put out the album "Appetite for Destruction" which I fell in love with and I still say that the drumming is what made these songs special. They fit perfect with Slash's guitar, Axel's voice and lyrics.

According to the sheet music that I have, this song is played in the key of E minor, but it changes to E major in the second solo and returns to E minor.

I do not have an echo to reproduce the opening measures, but I do what I can to mimic the effect - B minor pentatonic (B, D, E, F#, A). First lick, A blues scale (A,C,D,Eb,E,G). The riff over E and first solo are an E blues scale (E,G,A,Bb,D). The second solo played over E major, is a C# minor (C#,E,F#,G#,B), the E Mixolydian (E,F#,G#,A,B,C#,D), followed by B major pentatonic (B,C#,D#,F#,G#)

One take on the guitar track and two takes on the vocal's track
